'''Abdullah Al-Salloum''' ([[Arabic language|Arabic]]: عبد الله السلوم) (Tribe: Wuhiba, [[Banu Tamim]]) (born '''Abdullah Salim Abdullah Al-Salloum''', August 28, 1981) is a [[Kuwait]]i economist, entrepreneur, investor and author, who is known for his publications on the principles of political economics<ref name=":6">{{Cite news|url=http://news.kuwaittimes.net/website/kuwaiti-economist-explains-how-kuwait-can-benefit-from-saudis-vision-in-new-book/|title=Kuwaiti economist explains how Kuwait can benefit from Saudi's vision in new book - Kuwait Times|last=Kuwait Times|first=Newspaper|date=2018-09-02|work=kuwaittimes.com|access-date=2018-09-06|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite Al-Salloum|last=Alqabas|first=Newspaper|date=|website=alqabas.com|language=ar|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-08-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite Al-Salloum|last=Aljarida|first=Newspaper|date=|website=aljarida.com|language=ar|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-08-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://alqabas.com/605359/|title=Abdullah Al-Salloum: Knowledge for the Public Benefit|last=Alqabas|first=Newspaper|date=2018-11-20|work=alqabas.com|access-date=2018-11-26}}</ref>
== Views == ===Kuwaiti vision 2035=== Al-Salloum believes that Kuwaiti Vision 2035 has not followed the minimum standards of the [[Sustainable Development Goals|sustainable development]] vision concept. His rationale was based on the insufficient methodology used to set the goals of that vision; by which a vision is just a collection of goals that will definitely be achieved once previously planned giant and large projects are executed. Hence, this vision would not require a real strategy to follow other than waiting.<ref name=":6" />
===Saudi vision 2030=== Unlike Kuwaiti Vision 2035, Al-Salloum sees [[Saudi Vision 2030]] as a vision that follows reasonable standards of the [[Sustainable Development Goals|sustainable development]] vision concept; defending most of its strategies in a book of six chapters.<ref name=":6" /> The reason behind having Al-Salloum focusing on the [[Economy of Saudi Arabia|Saudi Arabian economy]] is the belief that [[Economy of Kuwait|Kuwait's economy]], once sustainable, will be attached to the closest largest economy, [[Economy of Saudi Arabia|Saudi Arabian]].<ref name=":6" />
===Diversified economy=== Al-Salloum's advised that following the leads of [[Macroeconomics|macroeconomic]] theories will be of an added value in moving the [[Gulf Cooperation Council|GCC]] economy from oil-based to diversified. Except for [[Kuwait]], the [[decision-making]] process in all other [[Gulf Cooperation Council|GCC]] is [[Centralized government|centralized]], where following those leads – in a direct manner – can be feasibly accomplished. For [[Kuwait]]'s case, however, and because of the very [[Democracy|distributed]] [[Decision-making|decision-making process]] made by [[democracy]], following those leads to have an effective economic reform must have a prior political reform.<ref name=":6" />
== Publications == ===Books=== * [[Kuwait of the Sustainability]] ([[Arabic language|Arabic]]: كويت الاستدامة): (Subtitled: ''Vision of a people, from and to them. -'' [[Arabic language|Arabic]]: رؤية شعب، منه وإليه.) ({{ISBN|978-1732537538}}) A political economic book that extensively highlights the [[Economy of Kuwait|Kuwaiti economy]] in particular, aiming at clarifying the concept of sound economic vision through radical solutions targeting [[Macroeconomics|macro­-economic]] issues of the state. In this title, which is introduced with appraisals by Prof. Ghanim Al­-Najjar – the political science professor at Kuwait University –, Ali Al­-Sanad, Ph.D. – the Islamic studies professor at the General Authority for Applied Education and Training –, and Mr. Mohammed Al­-Yousifi – the historical researcher and political analyst –, Al-Salloum looks forward to raise the awareness of the economic sense; in a way that makes individuals see and understand the consequences of political and administrative decision-making outcomes, build their own view and critical opinion while being fully aware of the subject matter. The title concludes that moving Kuwait from rent to sustainability requires a major reform at the [[Macroeconomics|macro-economic]] level, a reform whose impact would wipe all [[Political corruption|political]], [[Organizational behavior|organizational behavioral]], and [[Microeconomics|micro-economic]] obstacles facing the state.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://alqabas.com/607018/|title=Al-Salloum issues "Kuwait of the Sustainability"|last=Alqabas|first=Newspaper|date=|work=alqabas.com|access-date=2018-11-26|language=ar}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://al-seyassah.com/%D9%83%D9%88%D9%8A%D8%AA-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A7%D8%B3%D8%AA%D8%AF%D8%A7%D9%85%D8%A9-%D8%B1%D8%A4%D9%8A%D8%A9-%D9%88%D8%B7%D9%86%D9%8A%D8%A9-%D9%84%D8%A5%D8%B5%D9%84%D8%A7%D8%AD-%D8%A7%D9%82%D8%AA/|title=Kuwait of the Sustainability: National vision for a real economic reform|last=Al-Seyassah|first=Newspaper|date=2018-11-14|work=al-seyassah.com|access-date=2018-11-26}}</ref><ref name=":6" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.dasmannews.com/2018/11/%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B3%D9%84%D9%88%D9%85-%D9%8A%D8%B5%D8%AF%D8%B1-%D9%83%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%A8%D8%A7-%D8%A8%D8%B9%D9%86%D9%88%D8%A7%D9%86-%D9%83%D9%88%D9%8A%D8%AA-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A7%D8%B3%D8%AA%D8%AF/|title=Abdullah Al-Salloum Issues The Title "Kuwait of the Sustainability"|last=DasmanNews|first=Newspaper|date=2018-11-24|work=dasmannews.com|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://almada.cc/?p=335854|title=Abdullah Al-Salloum issues "Kuwait of the Sustainability"|last=Kuwaiti Almada|first=Newspaper|date=2018-11-24|work=almada.cc|access-date=}}</ref><ref name=":7" /> * [[Kingdom of the Vision]] ([[Arabic language|Arabic]]: مملكة الرؤية): (Subtitled: ''Within The Conflicts Of Sustainability And Rent -'' [[Arabic language|Arabic]]: بين مصارع الريعية والاستدامة) ({{ISBN|978-0692144862}}) An economic book that extensively elaborates on [[Saudi Vision 2030|Saudi Arabia's Vision 2030]]; linking its strategy to macroeconomics' theories.<ref name=":7" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.aljarida.com/articles/1532012742758956400/|title="Kingdom Of The Vision" Observes Economic Changes In Saudi Arabia|last=Aljarida|first=Newspaper|date=|website=aljarida.com|language=ar|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-20}}</ref><ref name=":6" /> The title was ranked as best-seller on [[Jamalon]] – middle-east's largest online book retailer – as well as on [[Amazon (company)|Amazon]]'s Arabic books' category.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Newspaper|first=Alqabas|date=|title=Kingdom Of The Vision: For A Sustainable Development|url=https://alqabas.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/16218.pdf|journal=Alqabas Newspaper|volume=Edition 16218 - Thursday, July 26th, 2018|pages=Page 14|via=}}</ref><ref name=":6" /> * [[The Currency of Mount Serenity]] ([[Arabic language|Arabic]]: مال جبال السكينة): A novel (Subtitled: ''The monetary system: from favor to post-tar-inar eras -'' [[Arabic language|Arabic]]: النظام المالي بين حقبتي الامتنان وما بعد الزفتينار) ({{ISBN|978-9996617980}}) that interprets – in a virtual world – the historic development eras of the real monetary system. The title was ranked as best-seller on [[Jamalon]]; middle-east's largest online books retailer.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.aljarida.com/articles/1501431758703834200/|title=The Currency of Mount Serenity: Mixture of Fiction and Reality|last=Aljarida|first=Newspaper|date=2017-07-31|website=aljarida.com|language=ar|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-08-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.okaz.com.sa/article/1563157|title=Al-Salloum Narrates History of The Monetary System Through The Currency of Mount Serenity|last=Okaz|first=Newspaper|date=2017-08-06|website=okaz.com.sa|language=ar|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-08-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.alyaum.com/article/4200929|title=The Currency of Mount Serenity: Mixture of Economics and Literature|last=Alyaum|first=Newspaper|date=2017-08-07|website=alyaum.com|language=ar|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-08-13}}</ref><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":7" />

== Accounting techniques == Al-Salloum has developed – then dedicated to public domain – [http://abdullah.com.kw/tools new accounting techniques] using an [[Open-source software|open-source]] code and gave it a – [[Creative Commons license|CC0]] – license to be developed and republished as part of [[social responsibility]].<ref name=":6" /> The techniques help [[Businessperson|businesspeople]] to easily create qualified and advanced [[Feasibility study|feasibility studies]] (managerial, [[Technical feasibility|technical]], financial and market feasibility, as well as [[Pricing strategies|pricing mechanism]]) by inserting basic information. These techniques also assist [[Household]]s rationalize their [[Expense]]s, to either raise savings or lower liabilities, with a minimum lifestyle change.<ref name=":3" /><ref>{{cite news|url=http://shulanews.com/?p=57166|title=Youth Startups: The Importance of Feasibility Studies|last=Shula|first=Newspaper|date=2017-04-30|work=shulanews.com|accessdate=2017-08-13|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=ar}}</ref><ref name=":2" /> The techniques have expanded to determine the valuation of running businesses for the purpose of acquisition or sale; creating more efficient negotiation outcomes.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://alqabas.com/491638/|title=Al-Salloum Develops A Business Valuation Technique|last=Alqabas|first=Newspaper|date=|work=Alqabas.com|access-date=2018-02-20|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=ar}}</ref> Al-Salloum has given free workshops on how such techniques can be utilized to get more realistic and reasonable results.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":4" /><ref name=":7" />

'''Alessandro Nelli''' (born [[Rome|Roma]], 28 January  1842 – [[Question mark|?]], ...) was an Italian entrepreneur. Nelli was the founder of the Fonderia Nelli (Nelli Foundry), which was the leading foundry in Rome from 1880 to 1900. Nelli worked for a number of artists, producing their artistic bronzes.

{{Infobox person | name = Alexandra Isles | image = | imagesize = | caption = | birthname = Alexandra Moltke | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1945|02|11}} | birth_place = [[Uppsala]], Sweden | death_date = | death_place = | children = Adam Isles | occupation = Actress | spouse = {{Marriage|Philip Henry Isles|1967|1976|reason=divorced}}; 1 child
[[Alfred Jaretzki III]] | parents = Mabel Wilson Moltke
Carl Moltke }} '''Alexandra Isles''' ('''née''' Moltke; born February 11, 1945) is a former actress and a documentary filmmaker. She appeared as the original [[Victoria Winters]] from 1966–68 on the cult TV serial ''[[Dark Shadows]]'', which aired on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] TV from 1966–1971. ==Background== Alexandra Moltke was born in [[Uppsala]], Sweden in 1945, of Danish and American parentage, the elder of two daughters, to Count Carl Adam Moltke, son of Count [[Carl Moltke (foreign minister)|Carl Moltke]], and Countess Mabel Moltke (née Wilson; formerly Wright). Count Carl Adam Moltke was a permanent member of the Danish Mission to the United Nations, and Countess Moltke was an editor at ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]''. Through her American grandmother, Cornelia Van Rensselaer Thayer, Alexandra and her younger sister, Victoria, are descended from the [[Livingston family|Livingston]], [[Schuyler family|Schuyler]], Bayard and Van Rensselaer families.{{IMDb name|0411308}} She attended the [[Chapin School]] in New York.[http://www.vanityfair.com/magazine/1985/08/vonbulow198508 Vanity Fair: "Fatal Charm: The Social Web of Claus von Bülow" BY Dominick Dunne] August 1985 ==Career== In 1985, she began work at the [[Museum of Television & Radio]] where she became a curator specializing in arts, drama and children's programming.[http://www.glimmerglassfilmdays.org/guest-speakers-2015/ Glimmerglass Film Days Guest Speakers 2015: "ALEXANDRA MOLTKE ISLES"] retrieved July 30, 2016 In 1991, a grant from the [[National Endowment for the Humanities]] launched her on a career as a producer and director of the award-winning documentaries ''The Power of Conscience: The Danish Resistance and Rescue of the Jews'' (1995); ''Scandalize My Name: Stories from the Blacklist'' (1999); ''Porraimos: Europe's Gypsies in the Holocaust'' (2002); ''The Healing Gardens of New York'' (2006); ''Hidden Treasures: Stories from a Great Museum'' (2011). Her films have been seen at the [[United States Holocaust Memorial Museum]] (Washington, DC), [[Museum of Modern Art]] (NY), and numerous film festivals including the [[Human Rights Watch]] and [[Margaret Mead Film Festival]]s, and all have aired on PBS. ==Personal life== In 1967 she married Philip Henry Isles II of the [[Lehman family|Lehman banking family]][https://www.nytimes.com/1967/07/11/archives/philip-h-isles-becomes-fiance-of-miss-moltke.html New York Times: "Philip H. Isles Becomes Fiance Of Miss Moltke"] at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in Manhattan. Having been divorced from her husband in 1976, she married, Alfred Jaretzki III, MD in 1991. {{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wybe87Ui7x8C&pg=PA261&lpg=PA261&dq=Alexandra+Isles+dark+shadows&source=bl&ots=M-Lfr-5QTz&sig=KFvzCsYCKQw_ZQ0enw-JB6IB4rk&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjfvrTdop_OAhXC6iYKHbkUA6g4ChDoAQhBMAc#v=onepage&q=Alexandra%20Isles%20dark%20shadows&f=false|first=Craig|last= Hamrick |title=Barnabas & Company: The Cast of the TV Classic Dark Shadows|page=261 |publisher=|date=|ISBN=}} She left ''Dark Shadows'' in 1968 because she was pregnant. In 1969, she gave birth to a son, Adam. During the early 1980s, she was subpoenaed, and testified, as a witness in the trial of [[Claus von Bülow]] for attempted murder of his wife, Sunny. According to newspaper accounts, Moltke and von Bülow had been having an affair.[https://www.nytimes.com/1985/05/29/us/key-witness-asserts-von-bulow-told-her-about-day-of-coma.html New York Times: "KEY WITNESS ASSERTS VON BULOW TOLD HER ABOUT DAY OF COMA" By JONATHAN FRIENDLY] May 29, 1985[https://www.nytimes.com/1985/05/28/us/key-witness-back-in-socialite-trial.html New York Times: "KEY WITNESS BACK IN SOCIALITE TRIAL"] May 28, 1985[https://www.nytimes.com/1985/04/11/us/key-witness-against-von-bulow-out-of-country.html New York Times: "KEY WITNESS AGAINST VON BULOW OUT OF COUNTRY" By JONATHAN FRIENDLY] April 11, 1985{{cite news|agency=Associated Press|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1817&dat=19820219&id=lSUdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=TqUEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5553,3985773|title=Alexandra Isles during testimony: 'Other woman' trial witness|date=February 19, 1982|publisher=''[[The Tuscaloosa News]]''|accessdate=January 21, 2014}}[https://books.google.com/books?id=tOcCAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA13&lpg=PA13&dq=Alexandra+Isles+bulow&source=bl&ots=8vIkp2mJmM&sig=nVyec89QUh-mW-YeLQDkKS5Mp0g&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjj4uPto57OAhWCyyYKHbjfBP0Q6AEIRjAJ#v=onepage&q=Alexandra%20Isles%20bulow&f=false New Yorker Magazine: "A Talk With Alexandra Isles" by Lally Weymouth] March 15, 1982[http://articles.latimes.com/1985-05-28/news/mn-16296_1_von-bulow Los Angeles Times: "Ex-Mistress Arrives Day Before Deadline Set by Court : Von Bulow Case Witness Returns to U.S."] May 28, 1985{{cite book|last1=Hamrick|first1=Craig|last2=Jamison|first2=R.J.|date=2012|title=Barnabas and Company: The Cast of the Tv Classic Dark Shadows|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wybe87Ui7x8C&pg=PA265&lpg=PA265&dq=Alexandra+Isles#v=onepage&q=Alexandra%20Isles&f=false|publisher=[[iUniverse]]|isbn=1475910320|accessdate=January 21, 2014}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== http://alexandraisles.com/alexandra.html {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Isles, Alexandra}} [[Category:1945 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Moltke family]] [[Category:Bayard family]] [[Category:Cornell family]] [[Category:Livingston family]] [[Category:Schuyler family]] [[Category:Van Rensselaer family]] [[Category:Lehman family]] [[Category:American television actresses]] [[Category:American people of Danish descent]] [[Category:American people of Dutch descent]] {{US-tv-actor-1940s-stub}}

directors]] | parent_organization = <!-- if one --> | subsidiaries = | affiliations = | budget = | slogan = The Global Voice of Quality | remarks = | footnotes = | name = American Society for Quality (ASQ) | former name = American Society for Quality Control | image_border = | size = <!-- default 200px --> | msize = <!-- map size, optional, default 250px --> | malt = <!-- map alt text --> | mcaption = | map2 = | abbreviation = ASQ | founder = <!-- or | founders = --> | merger = | location = | region_served = Worldwide | membership = 80000 (approximately) <small>(2013)</small> | general = <!-- Secretary General --> | num_staff = | num_volunteers = | website = {{URL|asq.org}} }} [[File:ASQ Registration booth 2010.jpg|thumb|ASQ registration booth at [[America's Center]] in [[St. Louis]] for the 2010 meeting on 24 May]] The '''American Society for Quality''' ('''ASQ'''), formerly the '''American Society for Quality Control''' ('''ASQC'''), is a knowledge-based global community of quality professionals, with nearly 80,000 members dedicated to promoting and advancing quality tools, principles, and practices in their workplaces and communities.
==History== ASQC was established on February 16, 1946 by 253 members in [[Milwaukee]], [[Wisconsin]], with [[George D. Edwards]] as its first president. The organization was first created as a way for quality experts and manufacturers to sustain quality-improvement techniques used during [[World War II]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://asq.org/about-asq/asq-timeline|title=The ASQ Timeline {{!}} ASQ|website=asq.org|access-date=2018-08-02}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://archives.library.illinois.edu/asq/asqhistory.html|title=ASQ Archives - A Brief History of ASQ|website=archives.library.illinois.edu|access-date=2018-08-02}}</ref>
In 1948, ASQC's Code of Ethics establishes standards for members to conduct their activities and business.
In 1997, the members of the organization voted to change its name from "American Society for Quality Control" to "American Society for Quality".<ref>[http://aqlinspectorsrule.com/Z1-4-2013.html AQL Inspector's Rule], accessed 28 November 2017</ref>
Today, ASQ is a global organization with members in more than 130 countries. ASQ operates regional centers in North Asia, South Asia, Latin America, the Middle East/Africa and has established strategic alliances with 28 organizations through the World Partners® Program<ref name="World Partners® {{!}} ASQ">{{Cite web|url=https://asq.org/global/world-partner-program|title=World Partners® {{!}} ASQ|website=asq.org|access-date=2018-07-26}}</ref> in countries like Brazil, Canada, and the United Arab Emirates to promote ASQ products and training.<ref name="World Partners® {{!}} ASQ"/>
== Quality == ASQ provides its members with [[professional certification|certification]], training, publications, conferences, and other services. Internationally, ASQ has formed relationships with [[nonprofit organization]]s that have comparable missions and principles, forming collaborative efforts to meet the quality needs of companies, individuals, and organizations. ASQ is a founding partner of the [[American Customer Satisfaction Index]] (ACSI), a quarterly [[economic indicator]].
Since 1989,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://asq.org/newsroom/news-releases/2013/20131203-malcolm-baldrige-national-quality-award.html|title=ASQ Receives New Contract for Malcolm Baldrige National Quality Award|website=asq.org|language=en-us|access-date=2018-07-26}}</ref> ASQ has administered the annual [[Malcolm Baldrige National Quality Award]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://asq.org/learn-about-quality/malcolm-baldrige-award/overview/overview.html | title=Malcolm Baldrige National Quality Award (MBNQA) | publisher=ASQ | accessdate=March 18, 2018}}</ref><ref name="JTMI">{{cite journal | url=https://scielo.conicyt.cl/scielo.php?script=sci_arttext&pid=S0718-27242009000100012 | title=Measuring Excellence: A Closer Look at Malcolm Baldrige National Quality Award Winners in the Manufacturing Category | author=Brian Cazzell, Jeffrey M. Ulmer | journal=Journal of Technology Management & Innovation | year=May 2009 | volume=4 | issue=1 | pages=134–142 | doi=10.4067/S0718-27242009000100012 | ISSN=0718-2724}}</ref> The ASQ also gives the [[Dorian Shainin]] Medal, which is awarded annually for the "Development and Application of Creative or Unique Statistical Approaches in the Solving of Problems Relative to the Quality of Product or Service".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://asq.org/about-asq/asq-awards/shainin|title=Shainin Medal - ASQ|author=|date=|publisher=|accessdate=23 October 2016}}</ref>
==Certifications== ASQ offers 18 professional certifications relating to various aspects of the quality profession. Exams are given nationally and, to a limited degree, worldwide several times annually. The [[body of knowledge]] for each certification is maintained through [[peer review]] every few years on a rotating schedule.
In 1968, the first ASQ certification was offered.<ref name="won">Newcomb, William O. "ASQ Certification: A Brief History". ''Quality Progress''. January 2010. p. 43.</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://videos.asq.org/asq-certification-at-50|title=ASQ Certification at 50|website=ASQTV|language=en|access-date=2018-08-02}}</ref>
In 2016, ASQ's certification exam delivery method changed from paper to computer based testing at Prometric nationwide testing facilities.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://asq.org/cert/computer-based-testing|title=Quality Certification Computer Based Testing by Prometric {{!}} ASQ|website=asq.org|access-date=2018-08-02}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.prometric.com/en-us/clients/asq/Pages/landing.aspx|title=Home|website=www.prometric.com|language=en-us|access-date=2018-08-02}}</ref>
All certifications listed are from this reference <ref name=won /> unless noted.

evaluation, and control. | |<ref>[http://asq.org/pdf/certification/inserts/cqe-insert-2006.pdf American Society for Quality Certified Quality Engineer brochure] – accessed 9 January 2010</ref> |- the broader scope of the quality manager's position. |<ref>[http://asq.org/pdf/certification/inserts/cmqoe-insert-2006.pdf American Society for Quality Certified Manager of Quality and Organizational and quality management. | |<ref>[http://asq.org/pdf/certification/inserts/csqe-insert-2009.pdf American Society for Quality Certified Software Quality Engineer borchure.] - accessed 9 January American Society for Quality Certified Quality Improvement Associate brochure.] - accessed 9 January 2010.</ref> |- |2001 |[[Six Sigma]] Black Belt |CSSBB |To demonstrate competency in Six Sigma methods. | |<ref>[http://asq.org/pdf/certification/inserts/cssbb-insert-2007.pdf American Society for Quality Certified Six Sigma Black Belt brochure.] - accessed 9 January 2010.</ref> |- |2002 Belt |CSSYB |Participates as a project team member. Reviews process improvements that support the project. |<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://asq.org/newsroom/news-releases/2015/20150304-asq-issues-9800-certifications-program-training.html|title=ASQ Issues 9,800 Certifications in Program Training Next Generation of Skilled Workers|website=asq.org|language=en-us|access-date=2018-07-26}}</ref> | |- |2016 |Supplier Quality Professional |CSQP |Works with an organization's supply chain and suppliers to continuously improve the performance of key system components by implementing process controls and developing quality assurance plans. | |<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://asq.org/cert/supplier-quality|title=Certified Supplier Quality Professional - How To Become CSQP Certified {{!}} ASQ|website=asq.org|access-date=2017-05-18}}</ref> |}
In a 2008 press release for the 40th anniversary of ASQ's certifications, the three most popular were the engineer (CQE), followed closely by the auditor (CQA) and the Six Sigma Black Belt (CSSBB).
== Publications == ASQ publishes a range of magazines and journals:<ref name="Publications">{{cite web | url=http://asq.org/pub/ | title=Magazines and Journals | publisher=ASQ | date=January 2018 | accessdate=March 20, 2018}}</ref> * '''''[http://asq.org/qualityprogress/ Quality Progress]''''', ASQ's flagship publication which appears monthly for more than 50 years. Each publication features in-depth articles describing the application of innovative methods and timely information about quality principles, tools, and techniques. The Quality Progress editorial staff strives to clearly present such material to readers, to stimulate discussion on what does and does not work, and provide the means by which individuals, organizations, and society can improve. Topics include knowledge management, process improvement, and organizational behavior. Full text access is available online from 1995–present to ASQ members and subscribers. Quarterly: * '''''[http://asq.org/pub/jqp/index.html Journal for Quality and Participation]''''', ASQ's peer-reviewed journal which appears four times per year in January, April, July, and October. Each publication features articles related to the education market and are focused on the people side of quality, particularly employee involvement, facilitation, and teams. Full text access is available online from 1987–present. * '''''[http://asq.org/pub/jqt/index.html Journal of Quality Technology]''''', ASQ's peer-reviewed journal which appears four times per year. Each publication features articles and papers that emphasize the practical applicability of new statistical techniques on design of experiments, process monitoring, reliability, and applied statistics. Papers present new methods, case study examples, comparisons of existing methods, and reviews of the literature on topics of current interest. Full text is available online from 1969–present to ASQ members and subscribers. * '''''[[Quality Engineering (journal)|Quality Engineering]]''''' (Co-published with [[Taylor & Francis]]), ASQ's peer-reviewed journal which appears four times per year. It's written for professionals in all engineering and management fields interested in quality improvement focusing on comprehensive quality science applications throughout the entire economy and society. Each publication features articles on the latest thinking on quality control and quality assurance management, related physical technology, associated statistical tools, standards information, and more. Full text is available online from 1988–present. * '''''[http://asq.org/pub/qmj/index.html Quality Management Journal]''''', ASQ's peer-reviewed journal which appears four times per year. It is considered is the first journal to link the efforts of academic researchers and quality management practitioners. Each publication aims to link the efforts of academic researchers and quality management practitioners by publishing significant research relevant to quality management practice and provide a forum for discussion of such research by academics and practitioners. Full text is available online from 1993–present to ASQ members and subscribers. * '''''[http://asq.org/pub/sixsigma/index.html Lean and Six Sigma Review]''''', ASQ's Lean and Six Sigma magazine which appears four times per year in February, May, August, and November. It's considered the first publication that addresses the specific needs of Six Sigma professions. Each publication features articles that provides a holistic view of Six Sigma, from the basics to the boardroom, by addressing the various professional development needs of Six Sigma Executives, Champions, Master Black Belts, Black Belts, Green Belts, and Yellow Belts. Full text access is available online from 2001–present. * '''''[http://asq.org/pub/sqp/index.html Software Quality Professional]''''', ASQ's peer-reviewed journal which appears four times per year in December, March, June, and September. Each publication features articles that focus on applying quality principles to the development and use of software and software-based systems. It publishes case studies, experience-based reports, and state-of-the-art reviews to provide practitioners with an understanding of those software quality practices that have proven effective in a wide range of industries, applications, and organizational settings. Full text is available online from 1998–present. * '''''[[Technometrics]]''''' (Co-published with the [[American Statistical Association]]), ASQ's statistics journal which appears four times per year. Each publication features articles that contribute to the development and use of statistical methods in the physical, chemical, and engineering sciences as well as information sciences and technology. It features papers that describe new statistical techniques; illustrate innovative applications of known statistical methods; or review methods, issues, or philosophy in a particular area of statistics or science. Full text is available online from 1959–present.
Division and Forum Publications: * '''''Quality Approaches in Higher Education''''' * '''''Quality Management Forum''''' * '''''Primers on Human Development and Leadership'''''
== Conferences == ASQ hosts a number of quality events and annual conferences worldwide:<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://asq.org/conferences-events.html|title=Quality Conferences and Events {{!}} ASQ|website=asq.org|language=en-us|access-date=2018-07-26}}</ref>
* [https://asq.org/conferences/wcqi World Conference on Quality and Improvement] * [https://asq.org/conferences/six-sigma Lean and Six Sigma Conference] * [https://asq.org/conferences/quality-4-0 Quality 4.0 Summit] * [https://asq.org/conferences/quality-space-defense Collaboration on Quality in the Space and Defense Industries] *[https://asq.org/conferences/inspection-division Inspection Division Conference] * [http://asq.org/conferences/latin-america-quality/ Latin America Conference on Quality, Improvement and Development] * [http://www.asqmeaconference.com/ MEA Regional Quality Conference] * [http://asq.org/conferences/european-quality/ European Quality Conference] * [http://asq.org/conferences/quality-education/ Quality Education Conference]
==See also== * [[European Foundation for Quality Management]] (EFQM) * [[Total Quality Management]] (TQM) * ''[[Technometrics]]''

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=November 2018}} The '''Biotechnology Regulatory Authority of India (BRAI)''' is a proposed regulatory body in India for uses of biotechnology products including [[genetically modified organism]]s (GMOs).<ref name=press_rel/> The institute was first suggested under the Biotechnology Regulatory Authority of India (BRAI) draft bill prepared by the [[Department of Biotechnology]] in 2008.<ref name=ver2008>{{cite web|title=Draft: National Biotechnology Regulatory Bill, 2008|url=https://www.indiaoppi.com/sites/default/files/PDF%20files/DRAFT%20NATIONAL%20BIOTECHNOLOGY%20REGULATORY%20BILL,%202008.PDF}}</ref> Since then, it has undergone several revisions.<ref name=2010_limbo>{{cite news|title=BRAI Bill leaves biotech commercialisation in limbo|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/brai-bill-leaves-biotech-commercialisation-in-limbo/article621692.ece|accessdate=24 March 2014|newspaper=[[The Hindu]]|date=9 September 2010}}</ref>
The bill has faced opposition from farmer groups and anti-GMO activists.<ref name=suman_sahai>{{cite news|title=Activists oppose Biotechnology Regulatory Authority of India bill|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/ahmedabad/report-activists-oppose-biotechnology-regulatory-authority-of-india-bill-1858894|accessdate=24 March 2014|newspaper=[[DNA India]]|date=9 July 2013}}</ref><ref name=no_brai_plz>{{cite news|title=No BRAI Bill, Please|url=http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/opinion/no-brai-bill-please/article5052683.ece|accessdate=24 March 2014|newspaper=[[Business Line]]|date=23 August 2013|author=Shaheen Contractor}}</ref>
==Overview== On 23 January 2003, India ratified the [[Cartagena Protocol]] which protects [[biodiversity]] from potential risks of [[genetically modified organism]]s, the products of modern biotechnology. The protocol requires setting up of a regulatory body.<ref name=CPB>{{cite web |title=Cartagena Protocol on Biosafety (CPB) |url=https://www.moef.nic.in/division/cartagena-protocol-biosafety-cpb |publisher=[[Ministry of Environment and Forests (India)]] |accessdate=24 March 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140707010921/http://www.moef.nic.in/division/cartagena-protocol-biosafety-cpb |archivedate=7 July 2014 |df= }}</ref> Currently, the Genetic Engineering Approvals Committee, a body under the [[Ministry of Environment and Forests (India)]] is responsible for approval of genetically engineered products in India. If the bill is passed, the responsibility will be taken over by the Environment Appraisal Panel, a sub-division of the BRAI.<ref name=2010_limbo/>
According to the bill, BRAI will have a Chairperson, two full-time members and two part-time members; all will be required to have expertise in [[life science]]s and biotechnology in agriculture, health care, environment and general biology. The bill also proposes setting up an inter-ministerial governing body, to oversee the performance of BRAI, and a National Biotechnology Advisory Council of stakeholders to provide feedback on the use of [[biotechnology]] products and organisms in the society.<ref name=press_rel/> The regulatory body will be an autonomous and statutory agency to regulate the research, transport, import, and manufacture [[biotechnology]] products and organisms.<ref name=press_rel>{{cite web|title=Regulatory Authority to be Set Up on Bio-Technology|url=http://pib.nic.in/newsite/erelease.aspx?relid=84347|publisher=Press Information Bureau, [[Government of India]]|accessdate=24 March 2014|date=22 May 2012}}</ref>
==Criticism==
[[Suman Sahai]], founder of the [[Gene Campaign]], has called the bill flawed. According to her, the bill is proposing new institutes without clearly defining their powers and responsibilities. She has also stated that the bill was introduced without consulting the people who will be affected by the bill.<ref name=suman_sahai/>
[[P. M. Bhargava]], founder of the [[Centre for Cellular and Molecular Biology]], has also opposed the bill. He has called the bill unconstitutional, as agricultural policy is the domain of state governments. He pointed out that the bill proposes formation of several subdivisions and has argued that they will consist of bureaucrats with no scientific knowledge. He has accused the [[Department of Biotechnology]], which will be involved in selection of members, as a promoter of genetic technology in India. He has pointed out that the broadly defined term "confidential commercial information" has been kept outside the purview of the [[Right to Information Act]]. He had stated that the bill uses vague wordings which would criminalize sequencing or isolation of DNA and PCR techniques, requiring approval for each usage. Thus, hindering research and education. He pointed out the bill has no provision for mandatory labelling of GM foods. He criticized giving the body power to punish parties making false or misleading statements about GM crops, calling it unprecedented.<ref name=bhargava>{{cite news|title=Unconstitutional, unethical, unscientific|url=http://www.thehindu.com/opinion/lead/unconstitutional-unethical-unscientific/article2752711.ece|accessdate=24 March 2014|newspaper=[[The Hindu]]|date=5 January 2012|author=[[Pushpa Mittra Bhargava|Pushpa M. Bhargava]]}}</ref>
In September 2010, [[Jairam Ramesh]], then Environment Minister, pointed out that the body is only deals with safety and efficacy of biotechnology products. The issue of commercialization has been left unaddressed. The decisions regarding commercialization can fall under the purview of [[Ministry of Environment and Forests (India)|Ministry of Environment and Forests]], [[Ministry of Health]], [[Ministry of Agriculture]], or [[Department of Science and Technology (India)|Department of Science and Technology]].<ref name=2010_limbo/>
On the other hand, [[Association of Biotechnology Led Enterprises]] (ABLE) has supported the bill. J.S. Rehman, an entomologist and a former member of the Review Committee on Genetic Manipulation, has stated that most protesters associate genetic engineering with [[Monsanto]], as a result development of Indian biotech is being hindered.<ref>{{cite news|title=Let’s unMonsanto the debate|url=http://www.thehindu.com/opinion/blogs/blogs-the-copernican/article5085741.ece|accessdate=1 April 2014|date=2 September 2013|author=Vasudevan Mukunth}}</ref>

The district has been represented by [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] [[Jimmy Gomez]] since June 2017. Its previous representative, Democrat [[Xavier Becerra]] of [[Los Angeles]], resigned January 24, 2017 to become [[Attorney General of California]]. Representative Gomez won a [[California's 34th congressional district special election, 2017|special election]] on June 6, 2017, beating fellow Democrat [[Robert Lee Ahn]] to replace Becerra.http://mynewsla.com/government/2017/06/07/traditionally-latino-congressional-seat-stays-with-latino-korean-american-defeated/ He was later sworn in as the District's Congressman on July 11, 2017.http://www.latimes.com/politics/essential/la-pol-ca-essential-politics-updates-los-angeles-rep-jimmy-gomez-sworn-1499817496-htmlstory.html {{Toclimit|2}} ==Geography== The district is almost entirely within the [[Los Angeles, California|City of Los Angeles]] and includes the following neighborhoods in Central, East and [[Northeast Los Angeles]]: {{col-begin}} {{col-break}} *[[Boyle Heights, Los Angeles|Boyle Heights]] *[[Chinatown, Los Angeles|Chinatown]] *[[City Terrace, California|City Terrace]] *[[Cypress Park, Los Angeles|Cypress Park]] *[[Downtown Los Angeles]] *[[Eagle Rock, Los Angeles|Eagle Rock]] {{col-break}} *[[El Sereno, Los Angeles|El Sereno]] *[[Garvanza, Los Angeles|Garvanza]] *[[Glassell Park, Los Angeles|Glassell Park]] *[[Highland Park, Los Angeles|Highland Park]] *[[Koreatown, Los Angeles|Koreatown]] *[[Little Bangladesh]] {{col-break}} *[[Little Tokyo, Los Angeles|Little Tokyo]] *[[Lincoln Heights, Los Angeles|Lincoln Heights]] *[[Montecito Heights, Los Angeles|Montecito Heights]] *[[Monterey Hills, Los Angeles|Monterey Hills]] *[[Mount Washington, Los Angeles|Mount Washington]] *[[Westlake, Los Angeles|Westlake]] {{col-end}} == Recent election results from statewide races == {| class=wikitable |- bgcolor="#EEEEEE" align="center" ! A '''core''' is a device used in [[casting]] and [[molding (process)|moulding]] processes to produce internal cavities and [[wikt:reentrant|reentrant]] angles (an interior angle that is greater than 180°). The core is normally a disposable item that is destroyed to get it out of the piece.<ref name="degarmo311">{{harvnb|Degarmo|Black|Kohser|2003|p=311}}.</ref> They are most commonly used in [[sand casting]], but are also used in [[die casting]] and [[injection moulding]].
For example, cores define multiple passages inside cast [[engine block]]s. One model of GM V-8 engine requires 5 dry-sand cores for every casting.<ref name="degarmo311"/>
==Materials required to make cores== *Core sand *Bentonite clay *Pulverized coal *Resin oil
==Advantages and disadvantages== Cores are useful for features that cannot tolerate [[draft (engineering)|draft]] or to provide detail that cannot otherwise be integrated into a core-less casting or mold.<ref name="degarmo311"/>
The main disadvantage is the additional cost to incorporate cores.<ref name="degarmo311"/>
==Requirements== There are seven requirements for cores:<ref name="degarmo312"/>
#Green strength: In the green condition, there must be adequate strength for handling #In the hardened state, it must be strong enough to handle the forces of casting; therefore, the compression strength should be 100 to 300 psi (0.69 to 2.07 MPa). #[[Permeability (foundry sand)|Permeability]] must be very high to allow for the escape of gases. #Friability: As the casting or molding cools, the core must be weak enough to break down as the material shrinks. Moreover, they must be easy to remove during [[wikt:shakeout|shakeout]]. #Good [[refractoriness]] is required as the core is usually surrounded by hot metal during casting or molding. #A smooth [[surface finish]]. #Minimum generation of gases during metal pouring.
==Types== Many types of cores are available. The selection of the correct type of core depends on production quantity, production rate, required precision, required surface finish, and the type of metal being used. For example, certain metals are sensitive to gases that are given off by certain types of core sands; other metals have too low of a melting point to properly break down the binder for removal during the shakeout.<ref name="degarmo312"/>
===Green-sand cores=== [[File:Green sand cores.svg|thumb|Green-sand cores]]
''[[Molding sand|Green-sand]] cores makes casting long narrow features difficult or impossible. Even for long features that can be cast it still leave much material to be machined. A typical application is a through hole in a casting.<ref name="degarmo312">{{harvnb|Degarmo|Black|Kohser|2003|p=312}}.</ref>
===Dry-sand cores=== The simplest way to make a dry-sand cores is in a ''dump core box'', in which sand is packed into the box and scraped level with the top. A wood or metal plate is then placed over the box, and then the two are flipped over and the core segment falls out of the core box. The core segment is then baked or hardened. Multiple core segments are then [[hot glue]]d together or attached by some other means. Any rough spots are [[filing (metalworking)|filed]] or [[sanding|sanded]] down. Finally, the core is lightly coated with [[graphite]], [[silica]], or [[mica]] to give a smoother [[surface finish]] and greater resistance to heat.<ref name="degarmo312"/> ''Single-piece cores'' do not need to be assembled because they are made in a ''split core box''. A split core box, like it sounds, is made of two halves and has at least one hole for sand to be introduced. For simple cores that have constant cross-sections they can be created on special core-producing [[extruding|extruders]]. The extrusions are then cut to the proper length and hardened. More complex single-piece cores can be made in a manner similar to [[injection molding]]s and [[die casting]]s.<ref name="degarmo312"/>
Types of core: *Cold Box *half core box *dump core box *split core box *left and right core box *gang core box *strickle core box *loose piece core box
===Lost cores=== {{Main|Fusible core injection molding}}
Cores are used for complex [[injection molding]]s in the [[fusible core injection molding]] process. First, a core is made from a [[fusible alloy]] or low melting temperature [[polymer]]. It is then placed inside the injection mold's dies and the plastic is shot into the mold. The molding is then removed from the mold with the core still in it. Finally, the core is melted or washed out of the molding in a hot bath.
==Binders== Special ''binders'' are introduced into core sands to add strength. The oldest binder was [[vegetable oil]], however now [[synthetic oil]] is used, in conjunction with [[cereal]] or [[clay]]. The core is then baked in a [[convection oven]] between {{convert|200|and|250|C|F}}. The heat causes the binder to [[cross-link]] or [[polymerize]]. While this process is simple, the dimensional accuracy is low.<ref>{{harvnb|Degarmo|Black|Kohser|2003|pp=312–313}}.</ref>
Another type of binder process is called the ''hot-box process'', which uses a [[thermoset]] and [[catalyst]] for a binder. The sand with the binder is packed into a core box that is heated to approximately {{convert|230|C|F|abbr=on}} (which is where the name originated from). The binder that touches the hot surface of the core box begins to [[cure]] within 10 to 30 seconds. Depending on the type of binder it may require further baking to fully cure.<ref name="degarmo313">{{harvnb|Degarmo|Black|Kohser|2003|p=313}}.</ref> Cores produced using this method are sometimes referred to as "shell-core" because often, only the outside layer of the core is hardened when in contact with the hot corebox. When the corebox is opened and the core removed, the uncured sand inside the core is dumped out to be reused. This practice can also be observed in some cold-box coremaking practices, though cold box shell-core making is much less common.
In a similar vein, the ''cold-box process'' uses a binder that is hardened through the use of special gases. The binder coated sand is packed into a core box and then sealed so that a curing gas can be introduced. These gases are often toxic (i.e. [[amine]] gas) or odorous (i.e. [[sulfur dioxide|SO<sub>2</sub>]]), so special handling systems must be used. However, because high temperatures are not required the core box can be made from metal, wood, or plastic. An added benefit is that hollow core can be formed if the gas is introduced via holes in the core surface which cause only the surface of the core to harden; the remaining sand is then just dumped out to be used again.<ref name="degarmo313"/> For example, a cold-box sand casting core binder is [[sodium silicate]] which hardens on exposure to [[carbon dioxide]].<ref name="bcs">{{Citation |title= Sodium silicate for core making |url= http://www.budgetcastingsupply.com/Sodium_Silicate.php |accessdate= 2009-08-02}}.</ref>
Special binders are used in ''air-set sands'' to produce core at room temperature. These sands do not require a gas catalyst because organic binders and a curing catalyst are mixed together in the sand which initiates the curing process. The only disadvantage with this is that after the catalyst is mixed in there is a short time to use the sand. A third way to produce room temperature cores is by [[shell molding]].<ref name="degarmo313"/>
The term ''no-bake sands'' can refer to either the cold-box process or air-set process.<ref name="degarmo313"/><ref name="bcs"/>
===Other considerations=== To increase the strength of cores internal wires and rods can be added. To enhance collapsibility, straw can be added to the middle of the core or a hollow core can be used. This attribute is especially important for steel casting because a large amount of shrinkage occurs.<ref name="degarmo313"/>
Except for very small cores, all cores require vent holes to release gases. These are usually formed by using small wires to create holes from the surface of the mold to the core. When this is not feasible [[cinder]] and [[coke (fuel)|coke]] can be added to the core to increase permeability.<ref name="degarmo313"/>
==Chaplets==<!-- [[Chaplet (metallurgy)]] links here --> [[File:Chaplets.svg|thumb|340px<!-- Image must be larger than 332 to display correctly -->|A diagram of chaplet usage]] [[File:Types of chaplets.png|thumb|Various types of chaplets.]]
If Fub≤0, no chaplet is used.
If Fub>0, chaplets is used.
As mentioned earlier, cores are usually supported by two core prints in the mold. However, there are situations where a core only uses one core print so other means are required to support the cantilevered end. These are usually supplied in the form of ''chaplets''. These are small metal supports that bridge the gap between the mold surface and the core. Since the chaplets become part of the casting, the chaplets must be of the same or similar material as the metal being cast. Moreover, their design must be optimized because if they are too small they will completely melt and allow the core to move, but if they are too big then their whole surface cannot melt and fuse with the poured metal. Their use should also be minimized because they can cause casting defects or create weak spots in the casting.<ref name="degarmo314">{{harvnb|Degarmo|Black|Kohser|2003|p=314}}.</ref> It is usually more critical to ensure the upper chaplets are stronger than the lower ones because the core will tend to float upward in the molten metal.<ref>{{Citation |last= Palmer |first= Reginald Heber |title= Foundry practice |page= 162 |publisher= Wiley |year= 1911 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=0qBIAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA162 |postscript=.}}</ref>
==Cheeks== [[File:Casting cheek.svg|thumb|left|340px<!-- This image must be larger than 332px to display correctly -->|A cheek used to create a pulley]]
When casting a reentrant angle, instead of using a core a ''cheek'' can be used. This is a third segment in the [[flask (casting)|flask]], in addition to the [[cope and drag]]. This allows the entire mold to be made from green sand and from removable patterns. The disadvantage of this is more mold-making operations are required, but it is usually advantageous when the quantities are low. However, if large quantities of casting are required, it is usually more cost effective to simply use a core.<ref name="degarmo314"/> {{Clear}}

[[Category:Casting (manufacturing)]] [[Category:Plastics industry]]

'''Corporate welfare''' is a term that [[Analogy|analogizes]] corporate [[subsidy|subsidies]] to [[Welfare|welfare payments]] for the poor.<ref name="NYT-20140327">{{cite news |last=Kristof |first=Nicholas |authorlink=Nicholas Kristof |title=A Nation of Takers? |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/03/27/opinion/kristof-a-nation-of-takers.html |date=March 27, 2014 |work=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=March 27, 2014}}</ref> The term is often used to describe a government's bestowal of [[Grant (money)|money grants]], [[tax break]]s, or other special favorable treatment for [[corporation]]s. It highlights how wealthy corporations are less in need of such treatment than the poor.<ref name="NYT-20140327"/>
The definition of corporate welfare is sometimes restricted to direct government subsidies of major corporations, excluding tax loopholes and all manner of regulatory and trade decisions, which, in practice, could be worth much more than any direct subsidies.
== Origin of term == The term "corporate welfare" was reportedly invented in 1956 by [[Ralph Nader]].<ref>{{Citation | title = Ralph Nader on Corporations | publisher = OnTheIssues | url = http://www.ontheissues.org/Celeb/Ralph_Nader_Corporations.htm | accessdate = 2014-09-03}}</ref><ref name="cwnader">{{cite book | title=Culture Wars: An Encyclopedia of Issues, Viewpoints, and Voices | publisher=M.E. Sharpe | author=Chapman, Roger | year=2010 | pages=119 | isbn=9780765617613}}</ref>
== Alternative adages == === "Socialism for the rich, capitalism for the poor" === Believed to have been first popularised by [[Michael Harrington]]'s 1962 book ''[[The Other America]]''<ref>Harrington 1962, p.170, quote: "socialism for the rich and private enterprise for the poor"</ref><ref>Robert P. Engvall (1996) ''[http://www.springerlink.com/content/c18j629841844765/ The connections between poverty discourse and educational reform: When did “Reform” become synonymous with inattention?]'' in ''[[The Urban Review]]'' Volume 28, Number 2 / June, 1996, pp. 141-163</ref> in which Harrington cited [[Charles Abrams]],<ref>[[Michael Harrington]] (1962) [[The Other America]], p.58, quote: ''This is yet another case of "socialism for the rich and free enterprise for the poor," as described by Charles Abrams in the housing field''</ref> a noted authority on [[House|housing]].
Variations on this adage have been used in criticisms of the [[United States]]' economic policy by [[Joe Biden]],<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/11/18/biden-on-the-bailout-soci_n_361900.html |title=Biden On The Bailout: 'Socialism For The Rich And Capitalism For The Poor' |last=Stein |first=Sam |date=18 March 2010 |website=The Huffington Post |access-date=13 April 2018 |quote=Pointing to the hundreds of billions of government dollars that have been spent to keep banks from failing, he recalled a "great expression" of his grandfather, Ambrose Finnegan: "It's socialism for the rich and capitalism for the poor,"" Biden said.}}</ref> [[Martin Luther King, Jr.]],<ref>[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9F0CEFDC113AF93BA25752C0A965958260&n=Top%2FReference%2FTimes%20Topics%2FPeople%2FK%2FKing%2C%20Martin%20Luther%20Jr. King's Light, Malcolm's Shadow], January 18, 1993</ref><ref>Thomas F. Jackson, Martin Luther King: ''From Civil Rights to Human Rights: Martin Luther King, Jr., and the Struggle for Economic Justice'', {{ISBN|0-8122-3969-5}}, {{ISBN|978-0-8122-3969-0}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=B8k6btUYR68C&pg=PA332 page 332]</ref> [[Gore Vidal]],<ref>Gore Vidal: [https://books.google.com/books?id=T4lBAAAAIAAJ Reflections Upon a Sinking Ship], Little, Brown, 1969</ref><ref>Gore Vidal: [http://www.countercurrents.org/us-vidal010904.htm Imperial America], September 1, 2004</ref><ref>[http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/opinion/2008/0920/1221835126413.html?via=mr 'Free enterprise for the poor, socialism for the rich': Vidal's claim gains leverage], irishtimes.com, September 20, 2008</ref> [[Joseph P. Kennedy II]],<ref>[http://www.metrowestdailynews.com/columnists/8998982778762559487 Kennedy: U.S. oil companies profit; Citgo helps the poor] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090227010823/http://www.metrowestdailynews.com/columnists/8998982778762559487 |date=2009-02-27 }}, MetroWest Daily News, January 24, 2007</ref> [[Robert F. Kennedy, Jr.]],<ref>Mark Jacobson: [http://nymag.com/news/politics/27340 American Jeremiad], ''[[New York Magazine]]'', February 5, 2007, see [http://nymag.com/news/politics/27340/index3.html page 4]</ref> [[Dean Baker]],<ref>{{cite book |last=Baker |first=Dean |title=The Conservative Nanny State: How the Wealthy Use the Government to Stay Rich and Get Richer |url=http://conservativenannystate.org/ |year=2006 |publisher=Center for Economic and Policy Research |location=Washington, D.C. |isbn= 1-4116-9395-7}} Reviewed in: Scott Piatkowski: [http://www.rabble.ca/columnists_full.shtml?x=50160 Socialism for the rich], [[rabble.ca]], May 25, 2006</ref> [[Noam Chomsky]],<ref>Noam Chomsky, "The Passion for Free Markets", ''[[Z Magazine]]'', May 1997. [http://www.chomsky.info/articles/199705--.htm Reproduced on Chomsky's official site].</ref> [[Robert Reich]],<ref>Interview with Jon Stewart, ''The Daily Show'', Oct 16, 2008: [http://www.thedailyshow.com/video/index.jhtml?videoId=188622&title=Robert-Reich Available at ''The Daily Show'' Site] </ref> [[John Pilger]],<ref>Full transcript of the John Pilger speech at the [[Sydney Opera House]] to mark his award of Australia's human rights prize, the Sydney Peace Prize: {{cite web |url=http://www.johnpilger.com/page.asp?partid=555 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-03-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101014234517/http://www.johnpilger.com/page.asp?partid=555 |archivedate=2010-10-14 |df= }}</ref> and [[Bernie Sanders]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=Sen. Sanders Held a Tax Cut Filibuster {{!}} C-SPAN |url=http://www.c-span.org/Events/Sen-Sanders-Held-a-Tax-Cut-Filibuster/20338/ |date=2014-01-18 |accessdate=2015-12-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140118010340/http://www.c-span.org/Events/Sen-Sanders-Held-a-Tax-Cut-Filibuster/20338/ |archivedate=January 18, 2014 }}</ref>
=== "Privatizing profits and socializing losses" === "Privatizing profits and socializing losses" refers to the idea that corporations want to reserve financial gains for themselves and pass along losses to the rest of society, potentially through lobbying the government for assistance. This practice was criticized in the [[Wall Street bailout]] of 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.investopedia.com/terms/p/privatizing-profits-and-socializing-losses.asp|title=Privatizing Profits And Socializing Losses|first=Investopedia|last=Staff|date=15 April 2012|website=investopedia.com}}</ref>
== United States == === Background === [[Subsidies]] considered excessive, unwarranted, wasteful, unfair, inefficient, or bought by [[lobbying]] are often called corporate welfare.<ref name="NYT-20140327" /> The label of corporate welfare is often used to decry projects advertised as benefiting the general welfare that spend a disproportionate amount of funds on large corporations, and often in uncompetitive, or [[anti-competitive]] ways. For instance, in the United States, [[agricultural subsidy|agricultural subsidies]] are usually portrayed as helping independent farmers stay afloat. However, the majority of income gained from commodity support programs actually goes to large [[agribusiness]] corporations such as [[Archer Daniels Midland]], as they own a considerably larger percentage of production.<ref>[http://www.usda.gov/factbook/chapter3.htm USDA: American Farms] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070210035144/http://www.usda.gov/factbook/chapter3.htm |date=2007-02-10 }} www.USDA.gov</ref>
Alan Peters and Peter Fisher, Associate Professors at the [[University of Iowa]],<ref>{{cite conference |url=https://www.bostonfed.org/-/media/Documents/neer/neer297f.pdf |title=Tax and Spending Incentives and Enterprise Zones |last1=Fisher |first1=Peter S. |last2=Peters |first2=Alan H. |date=March–April 1997 |publisher= [[Federal Reserve Bank of Boston|Boston Fed]] |pages=109–137 |location=Boston |conference=New England Economic Review}}</ref> have estimated that state and local governments provide $40–50 billion annually in economic development incentives,<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Fisher |first1=Peter |last2=Peters |first2=Alan |date=March 2004 |title=The Failures of Economic Development Incentives |url=http://www.crcworks.org/cfscced/fisher.pdf |journal=Journal of the American Planning Association |volume=70 |issue=1 |pages=27–37 |doi=10.1080/01944360408976336 |access-date=13 April 2018 }} </ref> which critics characterize as corporate welfare.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baltimorebrew.com/2011/07/14/tax-breaks-for-developers-economic-development-or-corporate-welfare/|title=Tax breaks for developers – economic development or corporate welfare? - Baltimore Brew|author=|date=|website=baltimorebrew.com}}</ref>
Some economists consider the [[Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008|2008 bank bailouts in the United States]] to be corporate welfare.<ref>{{Citation |url=http://www.smh.com.au/business/us-could-cut-deficit-and-gain-but-thats-unlikely-20101207-18oew.html |accessdate=2010-12-22 | title=US could cut deficit and gain, but that's unlikely| work=Sydney Morning Herald | first=Joseph | last=Stiglitz | date=December 8, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{Citation |url=https://economix.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/04/20/welfare-for-bankers/ |accessdate=2011-04-28 | title=Welfare for Bankers| work=The New York Times | first=Nancy | last=Folbre | date=April 20, 2009}}</ref> U.S. politicians have also contended that zero-interest loans from the [[Federal Reserve System]] to financial institutions during the [[Financial crisis of 2007-2010|global financial crisis]] were a hidden, backdoor form of corporate welfare.<ref>{{Citation |url=http://thehill.com/blogs/on-the-money/banking-financial-institutions/131487-sanders-uses-fed-disclosures-to-call-for-further-inquiry |accessdate=2010-12-15 | title=Sanders uses 'jaw-dropping' Fed disclosures to call for further inquiry | work=The Hill | first=Peter | last=Schroeder | date=December 1, 2010}}</ref> The term gained increased prominence in 2018 when Senator [[Bernie Sanders]] introduced a bill, singling out [[Amazon (company)|Amazon]] and [[Walmart]] in particular, to require a company with 500 or more employees to pay the full cost of welfare benefits received by its workers.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2018/9/5/17819450/bernie-sanders-stop-bezos-amazon-worker-pay-corporate-welfare-tax-bill|title=Bernie Sanders introduces "Stop BEZOS" bill to tax Amazon for underpaying workers|first=Adi|last=Robertson|publisher=The Verge|date=2018-09-05|accessdate=2018-09-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/bernie-sanders-amazon-walmart-with-100-tax/|title=Bernie Sanders targets Amazon, Walmart with 100% tax|first=Kate|last=Gibson|publisher=CBS|date=2018-09-05|accessdate=2018-09-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2018/9/5/17822810/bernie-sanders-bill-bezos-amazon-ro-khanna|title=Bernie Sanders's BEZOS bill takes aim at how Amazon pays workers|first=Emily|last=Stewart|publisher=Vox|date=2018-09-05|accessdate=2018-09-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/bernie-sanders-amazon_us_5b8eecade4b0511db3dcfd55|title=What the Bernie Sanders Amazon welfare fight is really about|first1=Arthur|last1=Delaney|first2=Dave|last2=Jamieson|publisher=Huffington Post|date=2018-09-05|accessdate=2018-09-14}}</ref>
=== Comprehensive analyses === ==== Cato Institute ==== [[Policy analysis]] conducted by the [[Cato Institute]], an [[Libertarianism in the United States|American libertarian]] [[think tank]], argued that [[United States]] [[Fiscal policy of the United States|fiscal policy]] allocated approximately {{US$|92 billion}} in the [[2006 United States federal budget|2006 federal budget]] toward programs that the authors considered to be corporate welfare.<ref name='Slivinski 2007-05-17'>{{cite journal | title = The Corporate Welfare State: How the Federal Government Subsidizes U.S. Businesses | journal = Policy Analysis | date = 2007-05-17 | first = Stephen | last = Slivinski | authorlink = Stephen Slivinski | publisher = [[Cato Institute]] | issue = 592 | url = http://www.cato.org/pubs/pas/pa592.pdf | format = PDF | accessdate = 2012-09-09}}</ref><ref name='WSJ 2011-11-08'>{{cite news | title = The Corporate Welfare State | date = 2011-11-08 | url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970204002304576631192120542046 | work = The Wall Street Journal | accessdate = 2012-09-09}}</ref> Subsequent analysis by the institute estimated that number to be {{US$|100 billion}} in the [[2012 United States federal budget|2012 federal budget]].<ref name='DeHaven 2012-07-25'>{{cite journal | title = Corporate Welfare in the Federal Budget | journal = Policy Analysis | date = 2012-07-25 | first = Tad | last = DeHaven | issue = 703 | url = http://www.cato.org/pubs/pas/PA703.pdf | publisher = [[Cato Institute]] | format = PDF | accessdate = 2012-09-09}}</ref><ref name='Bandow 2012-08-20'>{{cite news | first = Doug | last = Bandow | authorlink = Doug Bandow | title = Where to Cut the Federal Budget? Start by Killing Corporate Welfare | date = 2012-08-20 | url = https://www.forbes.com/sites/dougbandow/2012/08/20/where-to-cut-the-federal-budget-start-by-killing-corporate-welfare/ | work = Forbes | accessdate = 2012-09-09}}</ref><ref name='Hinkle 2012-09-05'>{{cite news | first = A. Barton | last = Hinkle | title = The Worst Welfare Benefits the Best-Off: Corporations | date = 2012-09-05 | publisher = [[Reason (magazine)|Reason]] | url = http://reason.com/archives/2012/09/05/the-worst-welfare-benefits-the-best-off | work = Richmond Times-Dispatch | accessdate = 2012-09-09}}</ref>
==== Independent ==== Daniel D. Huff, [[professor emeritus]] of [[social work]] at [[Boise State University]], published a comprehensive analysis of corporate welfare in 1993.<ref name='Huff 1993'>{{cite journal|title=Phantom Welfare: Public Relief for Corporate America |journal=Social Work |date=May 1993 |first=Daniel D. |last=Huff |author2=David A. Johnson |volume=38 |issue=3 |pages=311–316 |doi=10.1093/sw/38.3.311 |url=http://web1.boisestate.edu/socwork/dhuff/Nasw.htm |accessdate=2012-11-06 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6ByInyoNI?url=http://web1.boisestate.edu/socwork/dhuff/Nasw.htm |archivedate=2012-11-06 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Huff reasoned that a very conservative estimate of corporate welfare expenditures in the United States would have been at least {{US$|170 billion}} in 1990.<ref name='Huff 1993'/> Huff compared this number with [[social welfare]]: {{quote|In 1990 the federal government spent 4.7 billion dollars on all forms of international aid. Pollution control programs received 4.8 billion dollars of federal assistance while both secondary and elementary education were allotted only 8.4 billion dollars. More to the point, while more than 170 billion dollars is expended on assorted varieties of corporate welfare the federal government spends 11 billion dollars on Aid for Dependent Children. The most expensive means tested welfare program, Medicaid, costs the federal government 30 billion dollars a year or about half of the amount corporations receive each year through assorted tax breaks. S.S.I., the federal program for the disabled, receives 13 billion dollars while American businesses are given 17 billion in direct federal aid.<ref name='Huff 1993'/>}}
Huff argued that deliberate [[obfuscation]] was a complicating factor.<ref name='Huff 1993'/>
== United Kingdom == In 2015, Kevin Farnsworth, a senior lecturer in [[Social Policy]] at the [[University of York]] published a paper in which he claimed that the government was providing corporate subsidies of £93 billion.<ref name=farnsworthpaper>{{cite web|url=http://speri.dept.shef.ac.uk/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/SPERI-Paper-24-The-British-Corporate-Welfare-State.pdf |title=The British Corporate Welfare State: Public Provision for Private Businesses}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/jul/07/corporate-welfare-a-93bn-handshake |title=The £93bn handshake: businesses pocket huge subsidies and tax breaks}}</ref> This amount includes the role of the government in increasing trade, tax relief for businesses that invest in new plants and machinery (estimated by Farnsworth at £20 billion), not charging fuel duty on fuel used by railways or airlines, green energy subsidies, a lower corporation tax rate for small companies, [[regional development]] grants and government procurement for businesses (which Farnsworth suggests often favours British businesses even when these are not the best value option available).<ref name=farnsworthpaper /> However, ''[[The Register]]'' wrote that Farnsworth's figure for tax relief for investment was incorrect and that he had made mistakes in his calculations, noting that he was not an accountant. It also stated that not charging businesses taxes under certain circumstances (when the reliefs applied) was not the same as giving them a subsidy.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2015/07/12/political_memes_economics_corporate_welfare/?page=1 |title=Taxpayers are NOT giving businesses £93bn}}</ref> Fuel duty is not charged on airlines due to the [[Chicago Convention on International Civil Aviation|Convention on International Civil Aviation]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.icao.int/publications/pages/doc7300.aspx |title=Convention on International Civil Aviation}}</ref> (a [[United Nations|UN agency]]) which specifies that aeroplanes should be exempt from fuel duties.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://fullfact.org/factchecks/airline_industry_subsidies_green_taxes-3256 |title=Does the government subsidise airlines by £10 billion?}}</ref>
=== Political discussion === In 2015, [[Leader of the Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party leader]] [[Jeremy Corbyn]] said he would “strip out” the £93bn of “corporate tax relief and subsidies” Farnsworth referred to and use the proceeds for public investment.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/jeremy-corbyn-allies-accuse-chris-leslie-of-deliberately-misrepresenting-labour-leader-contenders-economic-policies-10436258.html|title=Jeremy Corbyn allies accuse Chris Leslie of deliberately misrepresenting Labour frontrunner's economic policies | location=London | work=The Independent|first=Andrew|last=Grice|date=3 August 2015}}</ref> Corbyn did not say which specific policies he would change. ''[[The Guardian]]'' wrote the policy "sounds wonderful, but careful scrutiny of 'corporate welfare' shows that it includes capital allowances designed to persuade companies to invest, regional aid to boost growth in rundown parts of the UK, and subsidies to keep bus and rail routes open – none of which Corbyn would presumably like to see stopped."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2015/aug/20/jeremy-corbyn-labour-leader-tory-economy-plans |title=Jeremy Corbyn has the vision, but his numbers don’t yet add up}}</ref>
== Canada == The [[New Democratic Party]] in [[Canada]] picked up the term as a major theme in its [[Canadian federal election, 1972|1972 federal election]] campaign. Its leader, [[David Lewis (politician)|David Lewis]], used the term in the title of his 1972 book, ''Louder Voices: The Corporate Welfare Bums''.<ref>{{cite book|title=Louder voices: the corporate welfare bums|last=Lewis|first=David|publisher=James Lewis & Samuel|year=1972|isbn=9780888620316|location=Toronto}}</ref>
The [[Reform Party of Canada|Reform Party]] and its successor the [[Canadian Alliance]] were known for opposing mostly business subsidies. However, after their merger with the [[Progressive Conservative Party of Canada candidates, 1997 Canadian federal election|Progressive Conservative]] party, they dropped their opposition to it. <ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=zxjshaowfeYC&pg=PT66&lpg=PT66&dq=reform+party+corporate+welfare&source=bl&ots=lDUyasx11z&sig=B8UXPouQ_G4D-7uKOFfwNe5J3Ok&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwj-k5v3oa3dAhXJmVkKHVqVCT04FBDoATACegQICBAB#v=onepage&q=reform%20party%20corporate%20welfare&f=false|title=A Nation of Serfs: How Canada's Political Culture Corrupts Canadian Values|last=Milke|first=Mark|date=2010-01-14|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=9780470675175|language=en}}</ref>
== India == It was observed by [[The Wire (Indian web publication)|The Wire]] that the [[Effective tax rate]] was low for the larger corporations which meant companies making smaller profits are competing in an unequal environment against bigger companies with substantial taxation benefits, with the gap in effective tax rates widening over the years.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://thewire.in/economy/why-52911-profitable-indian-companies-pay-0-tax|title=Why 52,911 Profitable Indian Companies Pay 0% Tax |website=The Wire|access-date=2018-03-25}}</ref> India's Union government's prime minister criticised this practice and said {{quote| "Why is it that subsidies going to the well-off are portrayed in a positive manner? Let me give you an example. The total revenue loss from incentives to corporate tax payers was over Rs 62,000 crore…I must confess I am surprised by the way words are used by experts on this matter. When a benefit is given to farmers or to the poor, experts and government officers normally call it a subsidy. However, I find that if a benefit is given to industry or commerce, it is usually an ‘incentive’ or a ‘subvention'."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/business/modi-calls-for-targeted-subsidies-questions-corporate-tax-breaks/story-IP1WX17PvJeyOfyLf0ZXxJ.html|title=Modi calls for targeted subsidies, questions corporate tax breaks|date=2016-01-30|work=[[Hindustan Times]]|access-date=2018-03-25|language=en}}</ref>}}
