revision.comment: Removed deprecated parameter(s) from [[Template:Columns-list]] using [[User:DeprecatedFixerBot| DeprecatedFixerBot]]. Questions? See [[Template:Div col#Usage of "cols" parameter]] or [[User talk:TheSandDoctor|msg TSD!]] (please mention that this is task #2!))
revision.text:
{{lead too short|date=January 2015}} The law for [[workplace bullying]] is given below for each country in detail. Further European countries with concrete antibullying legislation are Belgium, France, and The Netherlands.<ref name="antimoblegis">{{cite web |url=http://scholarworks.bgsu.edu/econ_pub/5/ |last = Browne |first =M. Neil |last2 = Smith |first2 = Mary Allison |title= Mobbing in the Workplace and Individualism: Antibullying Legislation in the United States, Europe and Canada. |publisher=Economics Faculty Publications |journal=Employee Rights and Employment Policy Journal |volume=12 |pages=131–159 |date=2008-08-08 | accessdate=2015-12-04}}</ref>
== Australia == Each state has its own legislation.
In [[Queensland]], legislation comes from Workplace Health and Safety Queensland. If bullying (referred to as 'Workplace Harassment' in the Queensland subordinate legislation) endangers a worker's health causing stress or any other physical harm, an obligation holders under the 'Workplace Health and Safety Act, 1995' can be found liable for not providing a safe place for their employees to work. Queensland is one of only two States in Australia with a Code of Practice specifically for workplace bullying – 'The Prevention of Workplace Harassment Code of Practice, 2004'<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.deir.qld.gov.au/workplace/law/codes/harassment/index.htm |title=Codes of practice – Workplace Health and Safety Queensland |publisher=Deir.qld.gov.au |accessdate=2012-08-01}}</ref> In [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], legislation comes from Worksafe Victoria. If bullying endangers a worker's health causing stress or any other physical harm, a corporation can be found liable for not providing a safe place for their employees to work.<ref name="worksafe">[http://www.worksafe.vic.gov.au/wps/wcm/connect/WorkSafe/Home/ Worksafe, Victorian Workcover Authority] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091030143610/http://www.worksafe.vic.gov.au/wps/wcm/connect/WorkSafe/Home/ |date=October 30, 2009 }}</ref>
== Canada ==
=== Quebec === The Canadian Province of [[Quebec]] passed legislation addressing workplace bullying on 1 June 2004. In its act representing labour standards, "psychological harassment" is prohibited. The Commission des normes du travail is the organization responsible for the application of this act.<ref name="travail">{{cite web |url= http://www.cnt.gouv.qc.ca/en/in-case-of/psychological-harassment-at-work/index.html |title=Psychological harassment at work – Commission des normes du travail du Québec |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |work=cnt.gouv.qc.ca |year=2010 |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref>
=== Ontario === Under the [[Ontario]] Occupational Health and Safety Act 1979, all employers "take every precaution reasonable in the circumstances for the protection of a worker". This includes protecting them against the risk of workplace violence.<ref name="oohsa">[http://www.labour.gov.on.ca/english/hs/ohsaguide/index.html Ontario Occupational Health and Safety Act 1979] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090925073905/http://www.labour.gov.on.ca/english/hs/ohsaguide/index.html |date=2009-09-25 }} Ministry of Labour, Ontario, Canada</ref> The Act requires establishment of Joint Occupational Health and Safety Committees for larger employers.
Under the act, workplace violence is defined as ''"...the attempted or actual exercise of any intentional physical force that causes or may cause physical injury to a worker. It also includes any threats which give a worker reasonable grounds to believe he or she is at risk of physical injury"''.<ref name="oohsa" /><ref name="VW">[http://www.labour.gov.on.ca/english/hs/workplace_violence.html Workplace Violence] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091012194651/http://www.labour.gov.on.ca/english/hs/workplace_violence.html |date=2009-10-12 }} Ministry of Labour, Ontario, Canada</ref> Currently, as the Act is written, the Ontario Occupational Health and Safety Act does not specifically cover the issue of psychological harassment.<ref name="oohsa" />
On 13 December 2007, MPP Andrea Horwath introduced for first reading a new Bill, Bill-29, to make an amendment to the Ontario Occupational Health and Safety Act. This Bill-29 is proposing "to protect workers from harassment and violence in the workplace" and will include protection from psychological abuse and bullying behaviors in the workplace in Ontario.<ref name="tp">{{cite web|url=http://www.ontla.on.ca/web/bills/bills_detail.do?locale=en&BillID=1938 |title=Legislative Assembly of Ontario, Canada |publisher=Ontla.on.ca |accessdate=2012-03-20}}</ref>
The Ontario OHS Act has been amended to include Bill 168, which came into force 15 June 2010. The amendment includes the protection of employees from psychological harassment, workplace violence, including domestic violence in the workplace.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ontla.on.ca/web/bills/bills_detail.do?locale=en&Intranet=&BillID=2181 |title=Legislative Assembly of Ontario, Canada |publisher=Ontla.on.ca |accessdate=2012-03-20}}</ref>
=== Saskatchewan === <!---<ref name="chrc">{{cite web|url=http://www.chrc-ccdp.ca|title=Canadian Human Rights Commission|website=www.chrc-ccdp.ca}}</ref>---> The Canadian Province of [[Saskatchewan]] made workplace bullying illegal in 2007 by passing The Occupational Health and Safety (Harassment Prevention) Amendment Act, 2007. The act broadened the definition of harassment, as defined in The Occupational Health and Safety Act 1993, to include psychological harassment.<ref>[http://www.qp.gov.sk.ca/documents/english/FirstRead/2006-07/Bill-66.pdf The Occupational Health and Safety] (Harassment Prevention) Amendment Act, 2007 in Saskatchewan</ref>
=== Manitoba === Manitoba enacted Bill 18 making bullying illegal and legitimized school "bullying clubs", Including [[gay-straight alliance]]s, and other school anti-bullying clubs. http://web2.gov.mb.ca/bills/40-2/b018e.php
== Ireland == In Republic of Ireland, there is a Code of Practice for employers and employees on the prevention and resolution of bullying at work.<ref name="copf">{{cite web|url=http://publications.hsa.ie/index.asp?docID=222 |title=Republic of Ireland – 2007 Code of Practice for Employers and Employees on the Prevention and Resolution of Bullying at Work |publisher=Publications.hsa.ie |date=31 July 2009 |accessdate=2012-03-20}}</ref> The Code notes the provision in the Safety, Health and Welfare Act 2005 requiring employers to manage work activities to prevent improper conduct or behaviour at work. The Code of Practice provides both employer and employee with the means and the machinery to identify and to stamp out bullying in the workplace in a way which benefits all sides. <!-- until a section on portuguese law is created, this bit is left commented out This is a news report on a case where a portuguese court found the portuguese state's national bank to be guilty of mobbing a employee {{cite news|url=http://dinheirodigital.sapo.pt/news.asp?section_id=21&id_news=175070 |title=Relação condena CGD a indemnizar trabalhador por «assédio moral» |publisher=Dinheiro Digital |date=3 February 2012}}-->
== Spain == In Spain, within the public administration, activities including preventing access to opportunities, physical or social isolation, withholding necessary information, keeping the target out of the loop, ignoring or excluding, if permanent and for a long time, are considered labor harassment and have to be prosecuted.<ref>Article [http://www.elpais.com/articulo/sociedad/Mantener/funcionario/desocupado/sera/acoso/laboral/elpepisoc/20110604elpepisoc_8/Tes Mantener a un funcionario desocupado será acoso laboral] in Spanish newspaper [[El País]] on 4. June 2011. Retrieved 4. June 2011, in Spanish Language</ref>
== Sweden == Workplace bullying in [[Sweden]] is covered by the ''Ordinance of the Swedish National Board of Occupational Safety and Health containing Provisions on measures against Victimization at Work'', which defines victimisation as ''"...recurrent reprehensible or distinctly negative actions which are directed against individual employees in an offensive manner and can result in those employees being placed outside the workplace community".''<ref name="vicwork">Ordinance of the Swedish National Board of Occupational Safety and Health containing Provisions on measures against Victimization at Work AFS 1993:17 [http://www.av.se/dokument/inenglish/legislations/eng9317.pdf Official English translation] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131030023948/http://www.av.se/dokument/inenglish/legislations/eng9317.pdf |date=2013-10-30 }}</ref>
The act places the onus on employers to plan and organise work so as to prevent victimisation and to make it clear to employees that victimisation is not acceptable. The employer is also responsible for the early detection of signs of victimisation, prompt counter measures to deal with victimisation and making support available to employees who have been targeted.
== United Kingdom == {{See also|Harassment in the United Kingdom|UK employment discrimination law}} In the United Kingdom, although bullying is not specifically mentioned in workplace legislation, there are means to obtain legal redress for bullying. The [[Protection from Harassment Act 1997]]<ref>[http://194.128.65.3/acts/acts1997/97040--a.htm#1 Protection from Harassment Act 1997]</ref> is a recent addition to the more traditional approaches using employment-only legislation. Notable cases include [[Majrowski v Guy's and St Thomas' NHS Trust]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/ld200506/ldjudgmt/jd060712/majro-1.htm#1|title=House of Lords - Majrowski (Respondent) v. Guy's and St. Thomas' NHS Trust (Appellants)|last=Department|first=Law Lords|date=|website=www.publications.parliament.uk|access-date=}}</ref> wherein it was held that an employer is vicariously liable for one employee's harassment of another, and Green v DB Group Services (UK) Ltd,<ref>[2006] [http://www.bailii.org/ew/cases/EWHC/QB/2006/1898.html EWHC 1898]</ref> where a bullied worker was awarded over £800,000 in damages. In the latter case, at paragraph 99, the judge Mr Justice Owen said "I am satisfied that the behaviour amounted to a deliberate and concerted campaign of bullying within the ordinary meaning of that term."
Bullying behaviour breaches other UK laws. An implied term of every [[employment contract]] in the UK is that parties to the contract have a (legal) duty of trust and confidence to each other. Bullying, or an employer tolerating bullying, typically breaches that contractual term. Such a breach creates circumstances entitling an employee to terminate his or her contract of employment without notice, which can lead to a finding by an [[Employment Tribunal]] of [[unfair dismissal]], colloquially called [[constructive dismissal]]. An employee bullied in response to asserting a statutory right can be compensated for the detriment under Part V of the [[Employment Rights Act 1996]], and if dismissed, Part X of the same Act provides that the dismissal is automatically unfair. Where a person is bullied on grounds of sex, race or disability ''et al.'', it is outlawed under anti-discrimination laws.
It was argued, following the obiter comments of [[Lord Hoffmann]] in [[Johnson v Unisys Ltd]] in March 2001,<ref name="jvu1">[https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/ld200001/ldjudgmt/jd010322/johnso-1.htm Judgments – Johnson (A.P.) v. Unisys Limited], Uk Parliament – Publications</ref><ref name="jvu2">[http://www.eoc-law.org.uk/default.aspx?page=3170 Johnson v Unisys Ltd [2001] IRLR 279 House of Lords], Case Summaries, Equal Opportunities Commission, UK</ref> that claims could be made before an Employment Tribunal for injury to feelings arising from unfair dismissal. It was re-established that this was not what the law provided, in Dunnachie v Kingston upon Hull City Council, July 2004<ref name="jvu3">{{cite web|author=Law Lords Department |url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/ld200304/ldjudgmt/jd040715/dunn-1.htm |title=Dunnachie v Kingston upon Hull City Council 2004 |publisher=Publications.parliament.uk |accessdate=2012-03-20}}</ref> wherein the Lords confirmed that the position established in ''[[Norton Tool v Tewson]]'' in 1972, that compensation for unfair dismissal was limited to financial loss alone. The compensatory award element for "ordinary" unfair dismissal is subject to a statutory cap set, from February 2014, at the lower of £76574 or 12 months gross pay. Discriminatory dismissal continues to attract compensation for injury to feelings and financial loss, and there is no statutory cap.
Access to justice in the UK is via self-representation at a tribunal, via a no-win no-fee lawyer, or via insurance or trade union lawyers. Since the Access to Justice act, "collective conditional fees" have blurred the distinction causing controversy for example in the case of Unison v Jervis.
== United States == In the United States, comprehensive workplace bullying legislation has not been passed by the federal government or by any US state, but since 2003 many state legislatures have considered bills.<ref name="San Francisco Chronicle 2007-01-21">{{cite web | last = Said | first = Caroline | title = Bullying bosses could be busted: Movement against worst workplace abusers gains momentum with proposed laws |work=San Francisco Chronicle |date=21 January 2007 | url = http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2007/01/21/BUG7DNKKN61.DTL | accessdate = 2007-10-19 }}</ref> {{As of|April 2009}}, 16 US states have proposed legislation; these are:<ref name="HWPB">{{cite web |url= http://www.healthyworkplacebill.org/ |title=The Healthy Workplace Bill – Workplace Bullying Legislation for the U.S. |work=healthyworkplacebill.org |year=2012 |accessdate=7 February 2012}}</ref> {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| * Nevada (2009) * Illinois (2009) * Utah (2009) * New Jersey (2007) * Washington (2007, 2005) * New York (2006)<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.nyhwa.org/index.html |title=Home – New York Healthy Workplace Advocates |work=nyhwa.org |year=2011 |accessdate=7 February 2012}}</ref> * Vermont (2007) * Oregon (2007, 2005) * Montana (2007) * Connecticut (2007) * Hawaii (2007, 2006, 2005, 2004) * Oklahoma (2007, 2004) * Kansas (2006) * Missouri (2006) * Massachusetts (2005)<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.mahealthyworkplace.com/support/thehealthyworkplacebill.html |title=Massachusetts Workplace Bullying Law |work=mahealthyworkplace.com |year=2011 |accessdate=7 February 2012}}</ref> * California (2003)<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.bullyfreeworkplace.org/id8.html |title=Healthy Workplace Bill |work=bullyfreeworkplace.org |year=2012 |accessdate=7 February 2012}}</ref> }} These workplace bullying bills would typically have allowed employees to sue their employers for creating an "abusive work environment", and most have been supported by the notion that laws against workplace bullying are necessary to protect public health. Many of the above bills are based upon the proposed Healthy Workplace Bill.<ref name="HWPB" /> This proposed bill contains several restrictive provisions not found in workplace anti-bully legislation adopted in other countries.<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.droitcivil.uottawa.ca/index.php?option=com_docman&task=doc_download&gid=2516 |title=The law of workplace bullying: an international overview |first=Katherine |last=Lippel |journal=Comp Labor Law Policy J |volume=32 |number=1 |date=Fall 2010 |page=12}}</ref>
Despite the lack of any federal or state law specifically on workplace bullying, some targets of bullying have prevailed in lawsuits that allege alternative theories, such as Intentional Infliction of Emotional Distress and Assault.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://abusergoestowork.com |title=Potential Statutory and Common Law Remedies for Workplace Bullying |publisher=When the Abuser Goes to Work |accessdate=12 February 2012 }}</ref>
Although most US states operate primarily under the doctrine of [[at-will]] employment (which, in theory, allows an employer to fire an employee for any reason or no reason at all), American workers have gained significant legal leverage through discrimination and harassment laws, workplace safety laws, union-protection laws. etc., such that it is illegal under federal and most states' laws to fire employees for many reasons. For example, these employment laws typically forbid retaliation for good faith complaints or the exercise of legal rights such as the right to organize a union. Discrimination and harassment laws enable employees to sue for creating a "[[hostile work environment]]", which can include bullying, but the bullying/hostility usually is tied in some way to a characteristic protected under the discrimination/harassment law, such as race, sex, religion, age, disability, sexual orientation, etc.
== South Korea == People can take legal action if specific action of workplace bullying is violated existing law or if it is recognized that laborer who is bullied in workplace suffer industrial accident, but generally it is hard to confirm whether it is illegal or not. Fundamentally, industrial accident can be approved when the accident have task correlation. However, it is hard to say that bullying is related with work. Besides bullying could be occurred in diverse places such as cafeteria, commuting bus, get -together so the task correlation is not likely to be approved. There is, however, a case about recognition of industrial accident related with workplace bullying. The court said that if laborer received treatment due to workplace bullying, it is an industrial accident and the person can take legal action.
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
{{Bullying}} {{Workplace}} {{Employment}}
[[Category:Business law]] [[Category:Workplace bullying]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} {{BLP sources|date=February 2009}} {{Infobox officeholder |name = Lin Hsin-i |native_name = {{nobold|林信義}} |native_name_lang = zh-tw |other_name = |honorific-suffix = |image = |nationality = [[Republic of China]] |order1 = |office1 = [[List of vice premiers of the Republic of China|Vice Premier]] of the [[Republic of China]] |premier1 = [[Yu Shyi-kun]] |term_start1 = 1 February 2002 |term_end1 = 20 May 2004 |predecessor1 = [[Lai In-Jaw]] |successor1 = [[Yeh Chu-lan]] |order2 = |office2 = Minister of the [[Council for Economic Planning and Development]] of the [[Executive Yuan]] |term_start2 = 1 February 2002 |term_end2 = 20 May 2004 |predecessor2 = [[Chen Po-chih]] |successor2 = [[Hu Sheng-cheng]] |order3 = |office3 = [[Ministry of Economic Affairs (Republic of China)|Minister of Economic Affairs]] of the [[Republic of China]] |term_start3 = 20 May 2000 |term_end3 = 1 February 2002 |predecessor3 = [[Wang Chih-kang]] |successor3 = [[Christine Tsung]] |birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1946|12|2}} |birth_place = [[Tainan]], [[Taiwan]] |death_date = |death_place = |party = |alma_mater = [[Taiwan Provincial Cheng Kung University]]
[[Oklahoma City University]]{{cite web |url=http://taiwanreview.nat.gov.tw/ct.asp?xItem=524&CtNode=1347 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-08-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131105160845/http://taiwanreview.nat.gov.tw/ct.asp?xItem=524&CtNode=1347 |archivedate=2013-11-05 |df= }} |occupation = Businessman |profession = }} {{Chinese name|[[Lin (surname)|Lin]]}} '''Lin Hsin-i''' ({{zh|t=林信義 |s=林信义 |first=t |p=Lín Xìnyì}}), a [[Taiwan]]ese businessman. He served in the [[Democratic Progressive Party]] administration as Minister of Economic Affairs between 2000 and 2002, then as Vice Premier between 2002 and 2004.{{cite news |title=Premier asks deputy, secretary to stay |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2004/04/17/2003136998 |work=[[Taipei Times]] |date=17 April 2004 |accessdate=12 March 2011 }} In November 2005, while a Senior Presidential Adviser, Lin attended the [[Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation]] (APEC) forum in [[Busan]], [[South Korea]], in place of Taiwan's President [[Chen Shui-bian]]. Because of opposition from the [[People's Republic of China]], Taiwan's senior leaders are unable to attend APEC events in person and must send a [[List of Chinese Taipei Representatives to APEC|ministerial-level envoy]]. He was Chairman of the [[Industrial Technology Research Institute]] from 2004 to 2008. A graduate of [[Taiwan Provincial Cheng Kung University]], Lin was an executive in the car industry before entering politics. ==See also== * [[List of vice premiers of the Republic of China]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{ROCVPMs}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lin, Hsin-I}} [[Category:Politicians of the Republic of China on Taiwan from Tainan]] [[Category:National Cheng Kung University alumni]] [[Category:Taiwanese businesspeople]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Taiwanese Ministers of Economic Affairs]] [[Category:1946 births]] [[Category:Oklahoma City University alumni]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of Brilliant Star]] {{Taiwan-business-bio-stub}} {{Taiwan-politician-stub}}

{{Infobox person | name = Mike Fry | image = MikeLFry.jpg | image_size = 180px | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1960|10|25}} | birth_place = [[Kankakee, Illinois]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2012|11|4|1960|10|25}} | death_place = Indianapolis, Indiana | occupation = [[Entrepreneur]], [[Trainer (business)|Trainer]], Entertainer, Marketing expert | website = [https://web.archive.org/web/20130613114828/http://mikefrylive.com/ mikefrylive.com] }} '''Michael L. "Mike" Fry''' (October 25, 1960 – November 4, 2012) was an American serial [[entrepreneur]], entertainer, trainer and marketing expert. He was the original [[Happy the Hobo]] on the [[children's television series]] ''[[Happy's Place]]'', and the creative mind behind and owner of [[Fancy Fortune Cookies]].
==Entertainer== Mike Fry was born in [[Kankakee, Illinois|Kankakee]], [[Illinois]]<ref>[http://www.bussellandbell.com/sitemaker/memsol.cgi?user_id=797273]{{dead link|date=September 2018}}</ref> but grew up in the [[Huntington, Indiana|Huntington]], [[Indiana]] area.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wane.com/dpp/entertainment/childrens-tv-icon-passes-away|title=Children's TV icon, Happy the Hobo, passes away|publisher=|date=2012-11-05|accessdate=2012-11-24|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121108021647/http://www.wane.com/dpp/entertainment/childrens-tv-icon-passes-away|archivedate=2012-11-08|df=}}</ref> He was the state [[Tae Kwon Do]] champion in 1979.<ref>''Huntington Herald Press'' "Five Are Awarded Tae Kwon Do Honors". October 1979</ref> He began [[juggling]] at the age of fourteen, after finding out that his grandfather used to juggle dirt clods on the farm in rural Illinois. By the age of 17 he was juggling for audiences in the local area.<ref>''Indianapolis News'' "Triple Time" August 7, 1995</ref>
Fry was accepted to the [[Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Clown College]], in [[Venice, Florida|Venice]], [[Florida]] at the age of 19, graduating in 1981. He toured with the circus for the 1981 and 1982 season. He had the honor of being trained by three of the world's four [[circus clown|Master Clowns]]: [[Lou Jacobs]], [[Frosty Little]], and Bobby Kay.<ref>''Indianapolis News'': "Hoosier Creates A New Idea In Fortune Cookies!" 1993</ref> He trained in heavy object balancing, which included six-foot tables, small canoes, a twenty-five foot ladder, a running chainsaw, other people, sofas, and a television set. In 1981, he became a [[Guinness Book of World Records]] record holder as part of a group that [[juggle]]d the most objects at one time.
He left Ringling Brothers in 1982 and made the transition to television, where he wrote and co-produced ''Happy's Place'', one of America's highest-rated children's television shows, from 1982 to 1990. ''Happy's Place'' aired on [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] affiliate [[WFFT-TV]] in 207 cities for eight years. At the height of the show's popularity there was a two-year wait for tickets to the show. He hosted a variety of guests from [[The Harlem Globetrotters]] to [[Jerry Mathers]] and [[Tiny Tim (musician)|Tiny Tim]].<ref>''Huntington Herald Press'' "Seeking Cookie Fortune". December 15, 1988</ref>
After leaving ''Happy's Place'', Fry trained at [[The Second City]] [[sketch comedy]] group in [[Chicago]]. While in Chicago he also auditioned to play the role of [[Bozo the Clown]], and did some writing for the show as a result. He was also an instructor at the Illinois Juggling Institute for one year while he lived in Chicago.<ref>''Fort Wayne News Sentinel'' "Clown moves to happier place". October 17, 1990</ref>
==Inventor== During his role as Happy the Hobo, Fry became interested in inventing. In 1988 he started marketing his first viable invention, America's first gourmet flavored [[fortune cookies]]. Since 1988 the company has greatly expanded on his original concept of gourmet fortune cookies, specializing in flavored, chocolate-dipped, giant, and decorated fortune cookies.<ref>Excelerations: Indiana's Growth 100. November 5, 1998</ref>
In 1990 Fry started developing and marketing another of his inventions, the "Always There Bear". He spent twelve years developing, marketing and refining the idea, culminating in his invention being purchased by [[Hasbro]] toys in 2002. His story is featured in the book ''The One Minute Millionaire'', by [[Mark Victor Hansen]] and Robert Allen. Fry worked with both Mark and Robert on the deal with Hasbro.<ref>[http://www.oneminutemillionaire.com/articles/toystory.asp One Minute Millionaire - The Toy Story: An Inventor’s Dream Come True] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061021124543/http://www.oneminutemillionaire.com/articles/toyStory.asp |date=2006-10-21 }}</ref>
His products have been used by [[Donald Trump]], [[Ozzy Osbourne]], [[Jay Leno]], [[Conan O'Brien]], [[Steven Spielberg]] and many other noted [[celebrities]].<ref>''Fort Wayne Journal Gazette'' "Wise Crackers: Hoosier inventor adds flavor buffet to fortune cookies". August 5, 2007</ref>
==Trainer== In 2004 Fry joined up with his long-time friend and mentor Linda Chandler as a part of her Core Value Training Program. He used his experiences as a marketer, entrepreneur and entertainer to teach internet marketing strategies to thousands of international business owners.<ref>[http://www.corevaluetraining.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=35&Itemid=45 CoreValue Training - CoreValue Team & Instructors] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081204024227/http://www.corevaluetraining.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=35&Itemid=45 |date=2008-12-04 }}</ref>
== Other works == Prior to his death, Fry was working on publishing his own children's joke book, using jokes from his live kids' show.{{fact|date=November 2016}} He had collected kids' joke books for many years, and he had a huge collection of them. Fry was also working on a book pertaining to goal-setting based around hours of interviews with [[adventurer]] and author [[John Goddard (adventurer)|John Goddard]], who greatly influenced Fry to start his own life-list at age 23.{{fact|date=November 2016}}
== Death == On November 4, 2012 it was announced that Mike Fry had died at the [[IU Medical Center]] in [[Indianapolis]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/indystar/obituary.aspx?pid=160927605#fbLoggedOut |title=Michael L. Fry Obituary: View Michael Fry's Obituary by The Indianapolis Star |publisher=Legacy.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-10}}</ref> He had suffered from an immune disorder for about 12 months. He was awaiting a liver transplant when he succumbed to the illness.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indianasnewscenter.com/news/gallery/Happy-the-Hobo-Dies-177236151.html|title=Happy the Hobo Dies|publisher=|date=2012-11-05|accessdate=2012-11-24|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121108011329/http://www.indianasnewscenter.com/news/gallery/Happy-the-Hobo-Dies-177236151.html|archivedate=2012-11-08|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news-sentinel.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20121105/NEWS/121109755/1009/LIFEEVENTS|title=Fort Wayne TV icon 'Happy the Hobo' dies|publisher=|date=2012-11-05|accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref>
==Media appearances==
=== Books === * ''Purple Cow'' (on-line edition) - Seth Godin: Seth Godin chose Mike Fry's Fancy Fortune Cookies as one of the most unusual niche food companies. * ''The One Minute Millionaire'' - Mark Victor Hansen and Robert Allen: Used Mike Fry's invention and story as the basis for a fictional storyline. * ''Wake up and Live the Life You Love'' - Steven E. and Lee Beard: Featured Mike Fry's inspirational story along with that of Dr. Wayne Dyer, Mark Victor Hansen, and John Assaraf. * ''Be Unreasonable'' - Paul Lemburg: Used Mike Fry's Fancy Fortune Cookies idea as an example of an "unreasonable" breakthrough and innovative business idea. * ''Fortune Cookie Chronicles'': Featured Fancy Fortune Cookies, and Mike Fry's invention of the gourmet fortune cookie as part of the history of the fortune cookie.
===Magazines=== * ''Indiana Business Magazine'': "It's No Secret: Four important business trends revealed in Indiana's Growth 100 companies"
===Newspapers=== * 1988 ''[[Herald Press]]{{siadn|date=April 2018}}'' "Seeking a cookie fortune." * 1993 ''[[New York Newsday]]'' "Clowning Around With Cookies." * 2002 ''[[Denver Daily News]]'' "Some people can't give up the fortunes." * 2007 ''[[Fort Wayne Journal Gazette]]'' "Wise Crackers: Hoosier inventor adds flavor buffet to fortune cookies." * 2007 ''[[Indianapolis Business Journal]]'' "Finding his fortune"
===Television=== * QVC: Fry appeared along with his Fancy Fortune Cookies on the show, sold out in less than three minutes.{{fact|date=November 2016}}
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100517091930/http://mikefrylive.com/ Official site] *[http://fancyfortunecookies.com/ Fancy Fortune Cookies web site]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Fry, Mike}} [[Category:1961 births]] [[Category:2012 deaths]] [[Category:American business theorists]] [[Category:Business speakers]]

{{pp-vandalism|small=yes}} {{BLP sources|date=November 2009}} {{Infobox politician | name = Nahyan bin Mubarak Al Nahyan | image = Nahyan Bin Mubarak Al Nahyan.jpg | order = [[Government of the United Arab Emirates|Minister of State for Tolerance]] | president = [[Khalifa bin Zayed Al Nahyan]] | primeminister = [[Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum]] | term_start = 20 October 2017 | term_end = | predecessor = [[Lubna Khalid Al Qasimi]] | successor = |office1 = [[Politics of the United Arab Emirates|Minister of Culture and Knowledge Development]]<ref name="SNBMAN">{{cite web |title=Members Of The Cabinet - Sheikh Nahayan Mabarak Al Nahayan |url=https://uaecabinet.ae/en/details/cabinet-members/his-excellency-sheikh-nahayan-mabarak-al-nahayan |website=uaecabinet.ae |language=en}}</ref> |term_start1 = 10 February 2016 |term_end1 = 20 October 2017 | president1 = [[Khalifa bin Zayed Al Nahyan]] | primeminister1 = [[Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum]] | predecessor1 = ''Post established'' | successor1 = [[Mohammed Al Gergawi]] |office2 = [[United Arab Emirates University|Chancellor of United Arab Emirates University]]<ref name="SNBMAN"/> |term_start2 = 1983 |term_end2 = 2013 |office3 = [[Higher Colleges of Technology|Chancellor of Higher Colleges of Technology]]<ref name="SNBMAN"/> |term_start3 = 1988 |term_end3 = 2013 |office4 = [[Zayed University|Chancellor of Zayed University]]<ref name="SNBMAN"/> |term_start4 = 1998 |term_end4 = 2013 | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = <!-- {{birth date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} for living people. For people who have died, use {{Birth date|YYYY|MM|DD}}. --> | birth_place = | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | nationality = [[United Arab Emirates|Emirati]] | other_names = | occupation = | years_active = | notable_works = | native_name = الشيخ نهيان بن مبارك آل نهيان | native_name_lang = at | relatives = {{plainlist| *[[Hamdan bin Mubarak Al Nahyan]] (brother) *[[Khalifa bin Zayed bin Khalifa Al Nahyan]] (great grandfather) }} }}
Sheikh '''Nahyan bin Mubarak Al Nahyan''' heads the [[United Arab Emirates]] Ministry of Culture, Youth, and Social Development.<ref>[http://www.thenational.ae/news/uae-news/new-look-uae-cabinet-sworn-in-by-sheikh-khalifa New-look UAE cabinet sworn in by Sheikh Khalifa]</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Sheikh Nahayan Mabarak Al Nahayan|url=http://www.pearlinitiative.org/sheikh-nahyan-bin-mubarak-al-nahyan.html|accessdate=25 May 2016|work=[[Pearl Initiative]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160521064146/http://pearlinitiative.org/sheikh-nahyan-bin-mubarak-al-nahyan.html|archivedate=21 May 2016|df=}}</ref>
==Career==
Prior to March 17, 2013, he headed the [[Ministry of Higher Education and Scientific Research (UAE)|Ministry of Higher Education and Scientific Research]].<ref>[http://www.whartondubai09.com/bio-alnahayan-2.html Biography of H.E. Sheikh Nahayan Mabarak Al Nahayan].</ref> He is the son of '''Mubarak bin Mohammed Al Nahyan''', grandson of Mohammad bin Khalifa bin Zayed Al Nahyan, great-grandson of [[Khalifa bin Zayed bin Khalifa Al Nahyan]], and great-great-grandson of [[Zayed bin Khalifa Al Nahyan]]. [[Hamdan bin Mubarak Al Nahyan]], Minister of Public Works, is his brother. Sheikh Nahyan was also Chancellor of two of the UAE's three government-sponsored institutions of higher learning: [[United Arab Emirates University]], established in 1976, and the [[Higher Colleges of Technology]], established in 1988; and president of the third, [[Zayed University]], established in 1998 until removed from these positions in April 2013.<ref>{{cite news|title=UAE Higher-Education Power Shifts: Phase 2|url=http://www.al-fanar.org/2013/04/uae-higher-education-power-shifts-phase-2/|accessdate=6 September 2013|newspaper=Al Fanar|date=16 Apr 2013}}</ref> He is also the [[Chairman]] of [[CERT (Centre of Excellence for Applied Research and Training)]], the commercial arm of the [[Higher Colleges of Technology]], established in 1996. For several years, Sheikh Nahyan has been the sponsor of the Emirates Natural History Group with chapters in [[Abu Dhabi]] and [[Al Ain]].<ref>[http://www.enhg.org/ Emirates Natural History Group].</ref> One of the two awards presented annually by the Abu Dhabi chapter is the Sh. Mubarak Award, named for Sheikh Nahyan's father.
==Investments==
Nahyan is Chairman of [[Warid Telecom|Warid Telecom International]] (a regional telecoms group based out of [[Abu Dhabi]] with operations in [[Pakistan]], [[Bangladesh]], [[Uganda]], [[Congo Brazzaville]], and [[Ivory Coast]]). He is also chairman of the [[Abu Dhabi Group]], [[Union National Bank]], and [[United Bank Limited]].
===Pakistan=== Nahyan has taken a keen interest in [[Pakistan–United Arab Emirates relations|Pakistan–United Arab Emirates Friendship]]. He is one of two Emirati royals, that own estate with a personal game reserve near the mouth of the [[Indus]] River in [[Sindh]] Province used for falconeering and hunting; the other royal being the late [[Sheikh Zayed]]. Nahyan's [[Abu Dhabi United Group]] is a large investor in [[Pakistan]]. It owns [[Bank Alfalah]], [[Warid Telecom]], [[Wateen Telecom]], Taavun and many more in Pakistan. He is also Founder Chairman of [[Bank Alfalah Limited|Bank Alfalah]].
Sheikh Nahyan Mubarak Al Nahyan is also recipient of Pakistan's highest civilian award, the [[Nishan-e-Pakistan#Recipients of the Hilal-e-Pakistan|Hilal-e-Pakistan]], which was conferred upon him by the President of Pakistan in 2005.
===Georgia=== In [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]], Nahyan invested in Kor Standard Bank (now Terabank) and [[Biltmore Hotel Tbilisi]].<ref name="agenda">{{cite news|title=Biltmore Hotel Tbilisi: Georgia's most luxurious hotel opens with impressive display|url=http://agenda.ge/news/62914/eng|accessdate=1 August 2016|work=agenda.ge|date=1 August 2016}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Ministry of Higher Education and Scientific Research]] * [[Abu Dhabi Music & Arts Foundation]]
==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Nahyan, Nahyan Bin Mubarak Al}} [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Abu Dhabi]] [[Category:Emirati politicians]] [[Category:Emirati businesspeople]] [[Category:University and college presidents]] [[Category:House of Al Nahyan|Nahyan Bin Mubarak Al]] [[Category:Government ministers of the United Arab Emirates]] [[Category:Zayed University faculty]]

revision.text:
'''Philippe Bourguignon''' (born 1948) is a [[France|French]] businessman who served as the chief executive officer of Euro Disney, executive vice president of Disney Europe,<ref>{{cite news|title=Euro Disney Chairman Bourguignon Gets Additional Post|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1996-10-22/business/fi-56392_1_euro-disney|accessdate=11 November 2016|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=22 October 1996}}</ref> the chairman and chief executive of Club Med, and the co-chief executive officer of the Davos-based [[World Economic Forum]] in 2003 and 2004.<ref>{{cite news|title=Eurotunnel: Winners and losers|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/3607195.stm|accessdate=11 November 2016|publisher=BBC News|date=7 April 2004}}</ref> He is vice chairman of Revolution Places,<ref>{{cite web|title=Revolution Team Members|url=http://revolution.com/team-member/philippe-bourguignon/|website=Revolution|accessdate=11 November 2016}}</ref> founded by [[America Online]] (AOL) cofounder [[Steve Case]] and is the executive co-chairman of Exclusive Resorts.<ref>{{cite news|title=Exclusive Resorts Appoints Cathy Ross As CEO|url=http://newsroom.exclusiveresorts.com/2015-05-14-Exclusive-Resorts-Appoints-Cathy-Ross-As-CEO|accessdate=11 November 2016|publisher=PR Newswire|date=14 May 2015}}</ref>
==Biography== Philippe Bourguignon was born in [[Salins-les-Bains|Salins]], [[France]]. He spent his boyhood in [[Morocco]], then as a teen moved to [[Aix-en-Provence]]. He has a master's degree in Economics from the [[Université Paul Cézanne Aix-Marseille III]] and holds a post-graduate diploma from the [[IAE Paris|Institut d'Administration des Entreprises de Paris]] (IAE Paris). Bourguignon is married with two children.
==Career== Bourguignon spent 14 years with the [[Accor]] group from 1974 to 1988, and was eventually promoted to President of Accor for the Asia/Pacific region. During this time he relocated to the US to develop the [[Sofitel]] and [[Novotel]] brands, and oversaw the construction of Novotel New York which opened in 1984.
While still in the U.S., Bourguignon was recruited by The [[Walt Disney Company]] as the head of real estate development. After joining Disney, he spent two years in California before relocating to Paris in October 1992 to be the CEO of [[Euro Disney]].
In 1997 Bourguignon was appointed Chairman and CEO of [[Club Méditerranée]] (Club Med), a position he held until 2003.In 2003, Bourguignon became Co-CEO of the World Economic Forum (known as Davos), and during 2005 he was the chairman of [[Aegis Media]] France. Bourguignon is currently Vice Chairman of Revolution Places, Executive Co-Chairman of Exclusive Resorts, Chairman of the advisory board of Primonial, the largest independent wealth management firm in France, and an active investor in OneRagtime<ref>{{cite web |author1=Bernard Dietsch |title=Rencontre Avec Philippe Bourguignon |url=https://www.forbes.fr/business/rencontre-avec-philippe-bourguignon/ |website=Forbes |publisher=Forbes |accessdate=14 June 2018 |language=French |date=14 December 2016}}</ref>, the venture platform that invests in early stage technology startups.
==Publishing== Philippe is a co-founder of the Monthly Barometer,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.monthlybarometer.com/|website=Monthly Barometer|accessdate=31 January 2017}}</ref> a subscription service that enables executives and leaders from around the world to anticipate and leverage emerging trends, using “contextual intelligence” methods to analyze the macro issues relevant to decision-makers.
In 2005, Philippe published his first book, Hop! a revealing discussion on the paradoxes of the world and the French economy.
==Boards== Philippe sits on the boards of [[CAVA (food company)|CAVA]], a fast casual Mediterranean food company founded in Washington, D.C.; [[Vinfolio]], serving wine-enthusiasts and collectors worldwide (USA); [[Neiman Marcus]]; Operation Hope; Positive Planet; Worldview; and is an adviser at startups including Busbud, SRS Acquiom, and Framebridge. He previously sat on the Boards of [[Zipcar]], a car sharing company (USA) that was acquired by [[Avis Budget Group|Avis]] and [[eBay]]. He was chairman of the "Scientific Committee of Law and Economics" at the French Ministry of Justice in 2004 and 2005) after being an adviser to the French Minister of foreign affairs in 2003.
Bourguignon was CEO of Miraval resorts,<ref>{{cite news|title=A Conversation with Philippe Bourguignon - CEO, Exclusive Resorts & CEO, Miraval|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZFH6nBCrtho|accessdate=11 November 2016|publisher=YouTube - Cornell School|date=19 December 2011}}</ref> an exclusive Tuscan-based spa resort. The first Miraval resort covered {{convert|400|acre|km2}} at the base of the Catalina Mountains near [[Tucson]], [[Arizona]]. In July 2011, Bourguignon was named CEO of Exclusive Resorts. Exclusive Resorts was founded in 2002 and has grown to be the world's largest and best destination club.
Philippe Bourguignon has been named [[Chevalier of the Legion of Honor]] and Officer in the [[Ordre national du Mérite]] in France, and received the Moroccan Wissam Al Alaoui Order.
==Personal== Philippe Bourguignon is married, and the father of two children. He races yachts with [[Bruno Peyron]] and set a record for crossing the English Channel. He also won the Bermuda World Series America’s Cup with Team New Zealand I in May 2016.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.lexpress.fr/actualite/economie/lorsqu-on-est-pdg-on-se-dit-qu-on-le-restera-toute-sa-vie_484599.html Interview with ''L'Express'' (2005)] {{fr}}
==See also== * [[Monique Mayère]]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Bourguignon, Philippe}} [[Category:French businesspeople]] [[Category:1948 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Chevaliers of the Légion d'honneur]]

'''John Rodney Turner''' (born 21 January 1953)<ref name="JRT-CV 2013">[http://www.polimi.it/fileadmin/_migrated/content_uploads/CV_Turner_Rodney.pdf John Rodney TURNER Summary Education and Qualifications], at ''polimi.it.'' 03.10.2013. Accessed 26.06.2017.</ref> is a British/New Zealand [[organizational theorist]] and Professor of [[Project Management]] at [[Skema Business School]] since 2004 and at the [[Kingston Business School]] since 2013.<ref name="PRT 2017">[http://business.kingston.ac.uk/staff/professor-rodney-turner Professor Rodney Turner] at ''business.kingston.ac.uk.'' Accessed 27.06.2017</ref> He is known for his work of [[project management]].<ref>Chapman, Chris, and Stephen Ward. ''Project risk management: processes, techniques, and insights.'' Wiley, 2003.</ref><ref>Jugdev, Kam, and Ralf Müller. "A retrospective look at our evolving understanding of project success." ''Project Management Institute,'' 2005.</ref>
== Biography == Turner obtained his [[B.Eng]] from the [[University of Auckland]] in 1973, his DPhil in Engineering Science and MSc in mathematics from in [[Worcester College, Oxford]] in 1977, and another Msc from [[Brasenose College, Oxford]] in 1979.<ref name="JRT-CV 2013"/>
Turner started his academic career as IBM Post-doctoral Research Fellow in 1977 at [[Oxford University]] in its Department of Engineering Science and at [[Brasenose College]]. After his graduation in 1979 he moved into industry, starting as mechanical engineer at [[Imperial Chemical Industries]]. The next six years he worked in management positions in process development, project management, machine design, construction and maintenance. In 1985 he moved into consultancy branch and was management consultant for [[Coopers & Lybrand Associates]] in the fields of manufacturing and project management.<ref name="JRT-CV 2013"/> There for three years he worked in the areas of shipbuilding, manufacturing, telecommunications, computing, finance, and government.<ref name="PRT 2017"/>
In 1989 he moved back to the academic world to the [[Henley Business School]] at the [[University of Reading]] as Director of Project Management, appointed Professor in 1994. In 1997 he moved to the [[Erasmus University Rotterdam]], where he served as Professor of Project Management until 2005. In those days he was also Operations Director in the process plant industry at the European Construction Institute. Since 2004 he is Professor of Project Management at the [[Skema Business School]]. From 2005 to 2009 he was also Professor of Project Management at [[Kemmy Business School]] at the [[University of Limerick]], at since 2013 Professor of Project Management at the [[Kingston Business School]].<ref name="JRT-CV 2013"/><ref name="PRT 2017"/>
Rodney served as chairman of the [[Association for Project Management]], and as chairman of the [[International Project Management Association]] from 1998-2000.
Turners research areas cover "project management in small to medium-enterprises, the management of complex projects, the governance of project management, including ethics and trust, project leadership and Human Resource Management in the project-oriented firm."<ref name="PRT 2017"/>
== Selected publications == * Turner, John Rodney. ''The handbook of project-based management: improving the processes for achieving strategic objectives.'' McGraw-Hill, 1993. * Turner, J. Rodney. ''Handbook of project-based management.'' McGraw-Hill Professional Publishing, 2008.
;Articles, a selection * Turner, J. Rodney, and Robert A. Cochrane. "Goals-and-methods matrix: coping with projects with ill defined goals and/or methods of achieving them." International Journal of project management 11.2 (1993): 93-102. * Turner, J. Rodney, and Ralf Müller. "On the nature of the project as a temporary organization." ''International journal of project management'' 21.1 (2003): 1-8. * Turner, John Rodney, and Ralf Müller. "The project manager's leadership style as a success factor on projects: A literature review." Project Management Institute, 2005.
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://business.kingston.ac.uk/staff/professor-rodney-turner Professor Rodney Turner] at ''business.kingston.ac.uk.''
{{Authority control}}

{{Use Jamaican English|date=February 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2015}} '''Rose Agatha Leon''' (20 October 1913 – 16 August 1999) was a Jamaican businesswoman and politician. In August 1999, she was murdered in her home.<ref> {{cite news | first = Glenroy | last = Sinclair | title = Madame Leon slain | date = 17 Aug 1999 | url = http://jamaica-gleaner.com/gleaner/19990817/f1.html | work = Jamaica Gleaner | accessdate = 2013-08-25 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071111181717/http://jamaica-gleaner.com/gleaner/19990817/f1.html | archivedate = 11 November 2007 | df = dmy-all }}</ref>
==Biography== ===Politics=== In 1948, she became the first woman to chair a national political party, the [[Jamaica Labour Party]], holding that position for 12 years.<ref name="guardian"> {{cite news | first = Yvette | last = Rowe | title = Rose Leon, Outspoken Jamican politician who always put people first | date = 23 August 1999 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/news/1999/aug/23/guardianobituaries1 | work = The guardian | accessdate = 2013-08-25}}</ref>In 1949, she was elected into the house of representatives, and in 1953 was appointed minister of health and social welfare.<ref name="Women Leadership"> {{cite web | url = http://www.guide2womenleaders.com/Jamaica.htm | title = Worldwide Guide to Women in Leadership | accessdate = 2013-08-25}}</ref> In 1960 she left the JLP due to its lack of support for the [[Federation of the West Indies]]. Soon after, she switched sides and joined the [[People's National Party]], returning to prominence in the late 1960s as a local councillor, and in 1971 as deputy mayor of Kingston. <ref name="guardian"/>From 1972-76 she was Minister of Local Government in the [[Michael Manley|Manley]] government.<ref name="Women Leadership"/>
===Cosmetics business=== Having returned to Jamaica from studying chemistry in the US, she founded the Leon School of Beauty Culture with her husband. She pioneered a line of locally-made beauty products, providing an alternative to imports. Right up until her death, Leon taught at the school.<ref name="guardian"/>
== References == {{Reflist}}

{{notability|date=April 2018}}
'''SMS Pro''' is an aviation [[safety management systems]] software package providing a web based SMS application, SMS training, and tools for aviation service providers to manage safety, security, quality, and quality issues worldwide.<ref>[https://jdasolutions.aero/news-events/newsletters/sms/june-2011-sms-newsletter.php June 2011 Newsletter] JDA Aviation Safety Solutions (1 June 2011)</ref>
SMS Pro is modeled after [[ICAO]] advisory material and the Four Pillars of SMS, and serves aviation service providers worldwide.<ref>[http://atcvantage.com/files/SMS_Software_Tools.pdf Aviation Safety Management Tools] Atc Vantage (9 August 2012)</ref> SMS Pro has been headquartered in Anchorage Alaska since 2004.
==Operations== SMS Pro is headquartered in Anchorage, Alaska, but provides SMS and risk management training all around the globe. They provide compliance guidance and other risk management educational material to providers based on guidance from major civil aviation authorities, including ICAO, [[FAA]], [[Transport Canada]], [[IS-BAO]], and [[EASA]].<ref>[https://skybrary.aero/bookshelf/books/3333.pdf SMS Scalability for Smaller Airlines] Flair air (12 February 2016)</ref>
SMS Pro is managed by NorthWest Data Solutions, which also develops commercial databases and web software.<ref>[https://www.yelp.com/biz/northwest-data-solutions-anchorage NorthWest Data Solutions] Yelp</ref><ref>[https://www.capterra.com/p/131588/SMS-Pro/ Capterra Business Software]</ref>
==Clients== SMS Pro was designed specifically for aviation safety management<ref>[https://www.mitrecaasd.org/SMS/doc/awareness/CWA_(small-operator)_SMS_Manual_Mar30_15.pdf Safety Management System Manual] Clearwater Air Inc (30 March 2015)</ref>, and has been adopted by airports, airlines, maintenance repair organizations, flight schools, quasi-military/police and private aircraft operators.<ref>[https://www.faa.gov/airports/airport_safety/safety_management_systems/external/pilot_studies/documentation/sea/media/seaSMSRoundtablePresent2011.pdf SMS In Practical Terms] FAA Briefing (2 November 2011)</ref>
While SMS Pro is one of the most recognized SMS software applications within the aviation industry, there has been no adoption outside of the aviation industry as of 2018. Industry references are only found within aviation, under the aviation software categories.<ref>[http://www.airlineupdate.com/content_subscription/aerospace_it/company_contact/smspro.htm Airline Update]</ref>
==Technology== SMS Pro is a web-based application based on Microsoft .NET platform using a MS SQL Server database. SMS Pro has recently made efforts to be adopted as part of State Safety Programs, but as of yet no State Safety Programs have been created.<ref>[https://www.tacgworldwide.com/CAA For Civil Aviation Authorities] Total Aviation Safety Solutions (Retrieved 11 April 2018)</ref>
==Scholarship== SMS Pro provides two $1,000 scholarships each year to students participating in aviation safety courses.<ref>[http://hubspot.aviation.wmich.edu/scholarships/scholarship-northwest-data-solutions Western Michigan University] SMS Pro Scholarship</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External Links== * [https://www.asms-pro.com/ SMS Pro official website]
[[Category:Aviation]] [[Category:Aviation safety]] [[Category:Aviation standards]]
{{software-stub}} {{aviation-stub}}

A '''space center''' is a place dedicated to space-related activity. It may be in [[public company|public]] or [[Private company|private]] ownership.
These activities may concern:
* [[Research]] * [[Manufacturing]] of major parts of [[space vehicle]]s * Launch of [[space vehicle]]s * [[In orbit]] control of [[space vehicle]]s * Government programs of a [[space agency]] * Public education at a specialist [[science museum]]
